speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (for the Minister of Finance) moved
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
that Bill C-63, an act to dissolve or terminate certain corporations and other bodies, be now read a second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Economics envelope.
He said: Madam Speaker, I rise to propose second reading of Bill C-63, an act to dissolve or terminate certain corporations or other public bodies.
As hon. members are aware, the government announced in the February budget that it will eliminate, consolidate, defer or privatize a total of 46 government agencies, boards, commissions, corporations or advisory bodies.

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
The Corporate Dissolutions Act is the first legislative measure giving effect to this commitment. It provides for the dissolution or termination of six government organizations, all of which were created by legislation.
The six organizations are: the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, the Law Reform Commission, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the Economic Council of Canada, the International Centre for Ocean Development and the Science Council of Canada.
This bill deals only with these six organizations because their dissolution or termination will not require substantial amendments to existing legislation. For the remaining organizations identified in our budget proposals, the required legislation will be introduced as expeditiously as possible.
Let me say a few words about each of the organizations affected by Bill C-63. They have all given valuable services to the people of Canada.
First, I would like to discuss the principles that underlie the government's decision to restructure and streamline its operations. This initiative is part of our commitment to respond to the clear desire of Canadians for a government that is leaner, more efficient and less expensive.
In pursuit of this objective, the government has taken a hard look at how it can eliminate overlap and duplication in its own operations.
We speak of the Government of Canada in the singular, but of course it actually consists of over 400 separate organizations and advisory bodies. These include not only 26 statutory government departments, but 80 departmental agencies, 56 Crown corporations and more than 200 boards, tribunals, councils and other advisory bodies.
The common denominator of these organizations is that they were all created to respond to what was perceived, at one time or another, as a particular public need. In more expansive times, the tendency was sometimes to create a new public body to meet new requirements, without necessarily examining whether these could be served within existing structures. Of course over time public needs have evolved and changed.
As a result of this process, some overlapping of functions and mandates has clearly occurred, but given
our heavy national debt and the high taxes this brings with it, that is something Canada can no longer afford. Accordingly, the government is undertaking to reduce the number of agencies, boards, commissions and advisory bodies it maintains, on the basis of five key principles.
First, we are eliminating waste resulting from overlap and duplication within the government. Second, we are eliminating waste resulting from duplication with the private sector. Third, we are strengthening particular sectors by consolidating related organizations and their mandates. Fourth, we are postponing desirable initiatives that we simply cannot afford at this time. And fifth, we will continue privatizing commercial operations that no longer serve the purposes of public policy.
Let me point out that these principles and the measures before us today are fully in keeping with the commitment to spending restraint, waste reduction and good fiscal management that our government has pursued since first coming to office. We have proved before, and are proving again, our willingness to take the tough decisions needed to ensure that taxpayers get the best value for their money.
I want to remind the House of some of these initiatives over the last eight years. Payments to VIA Rail and the CBC have been scaled back, and military bases have been closed. We have eliminated programs on home insulation, oil substitution and heavy water plants, so that federal energy subsidies last year were $2.4 billion less than in 1984-85. We have streamlined the operations of government and fully or partially privatized over 20 Crown corporations.
As a result, there are 90,000 fewer employees on the taxpayers' payroll today than eight years ago. We have rigorously controlled spending on the government's own operations, holding it to well below the rate of inflation. This means that the cost of government today is actually lower than it was when we came to office.

It is because of such action that the government this year will record an operating surplus of over $10 billion compared to the operating deficit of over $16 billion recorded in 1984-85. This translated directly into a lower deficit and a lower national debt than would have been the case had we not moved to control spending. The legislation before us represents further steps in this necessary process of good financial management.
April 30, 1992

It is perhaps inevitable that in the case of the organizations now being wound up or consolidated, those affected will interpret this as if government were reducing its commitment to these areas. Let me state very clearly that this is not the government's intention. The government believes that Canadians generally will welcome an initiative that will save taxpayers' dollars by eliminating functions that are not essential and by reducing overlap and duplication wherever possible.
The government believes that in many cases public policy actually can be better served by organizations that balance competing interests within themselves rather than by single interest agencies.
This is particularly true at a time when funds are scarce and people in every sector need to pool resources and work together rather than compete against one another. It makes little sense to incur expensive managerial and administrative costs by dividing functions among individual agencies simply because different interests argue that they should be represented separately.
The savings from these initiatives are estimated at $22 million in 1992-93 and will increase to $71 million by 1993-94. The savings over the next five years are estimated at $310 million.
Regrettably the restructuring will affect the employees of the organizations involved. We are estimating that there will be an over-all reduction of 500 jobs from the government payroll. However, employees who are public servants will be covered by the government's work force adjustment directive which emphasizes finding these people opportunities for alternative employment in the Public Service. Employees who are not public servants will be absorbed by other institutions or, if they are laid off, will be covered by the applicable employment policies of the organizations they work for.
Government Orders
I will turn now to the sixth organization that will be dissolved or terminated by this legislation.
The Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council is a statutory body that was established in 1977. Its members, who are drawn from management, labour and other interest groups, advise the Minister of Employment and Immigration on the department's policies and programs. The council is no longer needed as a statutory body since its labour market consultative function is now performed by the Canadian Labour Force Development Board. The immigration side of the department also has on-going consultative arrangements.
The Law Reform Commission was created in 1971. It has played a useful role in conducting an ongoing review of the statutes of Canada, in co-ordinating non-governmental research on legal issues, and in providing independent advice to the Minister of Justice.
The government has concluded, however, that these functions can be fulfilled without maintaining a separate organization. Responsibility for commissioning outside research will be assigned to the Department of Justice, with the minister and the department seeking the views of researchers and practitioners in universities and elsewhere. The Law Reform Commission will accordingly be wound up and any necessary continuing resources transferred to the Department of Justice.
The Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security was established in 1984. Its goal was to increase knowledge and understanding of the issues of peace and security from a Canadian perspective with particular emphasis on arms control, disarmament, defence and conflict resolution. Everyone would agree, of course, there are many other sources of independent foreign policy research and analysis. For these reasons we have concluded that we can no longer afford a separate government funded institute to provide these services.
The Economic Council of Canada was created in 1963. Over the years, the council has performed a valuable service in fulfilling its mandate to provide independent advice to the government on matters relating to the growth of Canada's economy. Since 1963, however, there

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
has also been an enormous growth in the amount and quality of work being done in this area at universities, by foundations and in the private sector. This has therefore diminished the council's role and reduced the justification for its claim on the limited funding available for arm's length research and advice.
The International Centre for Ocean Development was established in 1983. Its mandate is to support co-operation with developing countries to improve the management and use of ocean resources. This role distinctly overlaps that of CIDA, the Canadian International Development Agency, and clearly does not justify the overhead cost of a separate organization. Therefore CIDA will take appropriate measures to ensure that assistance in relation to ocean resources continues to be provided to developing countries.
The Science Council of Canada has played a useful role since it was created in 1966. That role has been to provide advice to the government and to stimulate research and debate on issues of science policy. However, as in the case of economic issues, the establishment of institutes and centres of research in science and technology by universities, industry and other sectors has greatly expanded-everyone will agree-the sources of independent information and advice in Canada.
In addition, the National Advisory Board on Science and Technology, composed of prominent Canadians and chaired by the Prime Minister, now provides advice on a broad range of science and technology issues.
The streamlining and restructuring of government operations announced in the budget will improve the efficiency of the Public Service. It will also save money, savings that are essential if we are to reduce the burden of deficits and public debt that have contributed so painfully to heavy taxes, inflationary pressure and higher interest rates.

We deeply regret that there will necessarily be some lay-offs. We regret any lay-offs, in the public or the private sector, but government and those who work for it should not be exempt from the obligation to increase efficiency and control costs that the business sector and its employees face every day.
I would also call attention to the other measures announced in the budget that are aimed at improving service to the public.
These measures include a department-by-department review of regulations to cut down on red tape, and steps by federal departments and agencies that offer related services to individuals and businesses to bring those services together in one place. They also include simplified procedures for businesses in their dealings with government, greater use of simplified tax forms and more accessible hours of service by government offices.
In conclusion, these measures and the reduction in the number of government agencies are not spectacular changes made to obtain immediate results and have an immediate impact. They are simply ways to provide a Public Service at lower cost.
In taking these measures, the government is doing what must be done for a stronger, more productive and more competitive economy, which is the key to the long-term prosperity of all Canadians.

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to commence debate for the Official Opposition in relation to Bill C-63.
I am not in a position to indicate any kind of support for this government bill. The opposition regrets both the need for the bill and the substance of it.
The bill masquerades under several guises. Basically the bill removes from the public scene agencies and initiatives which have served Canadians well for many years.
Is the purpose of this bill privatization? It is not because in many instances the functions that these agencies represent will stay within government. They will be buried in government ministries and their independent role will be taken away from them. Is it reform? There might be just a tinge of administrative reform buried in the process but I am of the view that it is not reform at all. It is simply chopping a set of quality government functions and buiying them in the Public Service or eliminating them.
It is in fact a retrenchment of government function back within government, out of the eye of the public. There is nothing new in this type of consolidation. If there was any redundancy, and it is always possible that there is some redundancy in government function over the broad spectrum, then it was certainly possible to address the redundancy. If the redundancy was in the
April 30, 1992

ministries then it was possible to remove the redundancy from the ministries. Instead, the government is taking aim at agencies which it had created as independent agencies.
What we are doing here is purging from government the independent consultation and advice that government so often needs in this very complex world.
Publicly there is a recognition that from time to time, governments can lose their independent perspective, their edge, their objectivity and even their creativity by constantly having to rely on a ministry that works within itself in one place, in one environment with the same people over long careers. What develops in that environment is a tendency to tell the boss exactly what the boss wants to hear. There is a loss of independence, of creativity. Nobody wants to be the person to bring the bad news to the boss. There is a loss of independence and creativity and it is that independence and potential creativity which is about to be squeezed out, amputated from the government function in Canada.
There is a difficulty here and it has been raised in the House before this in dealing with six agencies in one bill. Perhaps an aspect of an agency function might be redundant, which should be reformed in some way. But it is extremely difficult for the opposition to deal with one agency among six in a bill that the government is insistent will be carried in one package. It lumps all of these agencies together. It does not permit the opposition to effectively deal with each one on an individual basis.
I should not be too cynical, but if it is an attempt to divide and conquer the opposition by dividing opposition to the bill among half a dozen or more critics or various segments of expertise, I say that is not going to happen. Rather than divide and conquer, the way this bill has been presented is shaping up into a rallying cry for the opposition.
The way the bill has been crafted and presented is not good for the way Parliament functions.
The source of this legislation was in the last budget speech on February 25. In that speech there were references to a government plan, and I quote: "To eliminate, consolidate, defer and privatize some 46 Crown agencies, boards, commissions, corporations and advisory bodies". One asks the reason why. Was it
Government Orders
because these agencies were not fulfilling their function or had ceased to fill their function? From my perspective in almost every case, the answer to that is no.
There may be the odd one among the 46 that does not have to be with government any more. There may be the odd one that the government in a true privatization initiative wishes to sell, take back the money and spin off into the private sector. That might be all right on a case-by-case basis.
In this particular bill we are only dealing with six. We are not dealing with the 46. Therefore, we are not getting rid of these agencies because their job was finished. The remarks in this debate I am sure will show clearly that the job is not done. The functions and the goals of bettering government persist.
In his speech the Minister of Finance has called this initiative streamlining. That has a nice ring to it. Streamlining sounds sleek and smooth. It sounds nice. It even has a dynamic ring to it, but for all the 46 agencies concerned here, this is not an honest term.
It is elimination, cutting out, discarding, getting rid of an agency. I suggest that we are not going to buy the euphemism of streamlining. That is a little bit like a surgeon who takes a look at a leg infected with gangrene and says it has to come off and tells the patient: "I think we are going to have to streamline your body". What we are talking about here is an amputation. We will not be fooled by that and I do not think the public is going to be fooled.
There is an element here of cost-cutting. The government is attempting to reduce costs. It is worth looking at and we want to address that in this debate. I know I certainly will. What the government is doing here is like what I do with my beer and pop bottles when they are empty. I take them back for recycling. I get rid of them. But the bottle here is not empty. The valuable work of these agencies carries on. It was as recent as yesterday that this House dealt with issues contained in a report of just one of these agencies.
Therefore, let us take a closer look at some of the agencies that are about to be amputated. There are six. Not in any particular order, there is the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council; the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security; the Economic Council of Canada; the International Centre for

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
Ocean Development; the Law Reform Commission of Canada and the Science Council of Canada. Most Canadians have heard of at least half of those agencies. Many Canadians, whether they know it or not, have relied on and have taken benefit from the work of those agencies.
Let us look firstly at the Science Council of Canada. This particular agency has provided guidance and research analysis and has made recommendations and studies in many, many areas. I just want to put a few on the record. They are too numerous to deal with here in total, but it has a publications list. I want to refer to the generic list of publications rather than each one just so Canadians can know what we are not going to have from this agency any more. All of this will be history. You will be able to find it in a library.
If Canadians hear of anything in this debate that they might want to read up on, and perhaps they might, the publication can probably be found in the local library: on biology, biotechnology, climate, computers and information technology, education, energy, forestry, micro-electronics, the north, pollution and environmental hazards, recycling, space, technology transfer, transportation, urban development, water resources and wildlife. That is just a partial list of the areas that have been studied by the Science Council of Canada, not just studied but recommendations have been made, read, studied, taught, analysed and hopefully incorporated into government policy over time.
The mandate of this agency is to assess scientific and technological resources, the requirements and potential of these for Canada and to increase public awareness of Canada's scientific and technological problems and opportunities. That is precisely where Canada should be spending its money, on its opportunities in all of those areas.
The list I just went through contained as reasonable a list of winners as Canadians are ever going to find. As we go through this debate they are going to hear about other winners. These winners are all on the chopping block. As Canada makes a concerted effort to become more competitive domestically and internationally it is exactly this kind of advice and leadership that Canadians need.
The second agency I want to speak about is the Economic Council of Canada which has served Canadians for almost 30 years. Barely a month or a week goes by without some journalistic endeavour or some public debate that makes reference to the work of the Economic Council of Canada.
This particular agency provides and has provided to Canadians over all of these years honest, objective, independent and quality advice on numerous subjects. One of the more recent ones involved the potential economic implications of the separation from Canada of the province of Quebec.
I ask where is this government going to get advice on that issue, advice that is independent and objective, if it does not get it from an independent agency? That kind of analysis and study could not objectively take place within government and find its way into policy-making. Whatever those studies inside government would reveal they would be buried.
There is not a minister sitting on that side of the House who would get his fingers caught, get his pantlegs caught in that kind of an initiative for all the tea in China. He would not do it. The only way that work is going to get done objectively and fairly is outside government. That kind of information is often so politically sensitive that the only one who is ever going to go public, and this is understandable, would be the Prime Minister or the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs.
However, the information is very real. It is essential that Canadians know this stuff. In any event, without the independent agency, the matters are buried within government and once it is in there it does not get out because it is all advice to minister.
We all know that the Access to Information Act, under the law of Canada, says that advice to a minister is privileged and confidential. It cannot be seen. Maybe 25 years later you might get a good look at it, but nowhere will that information enter into public debate.
We have reports from the Economic Council of Canada on productivity. Did you ever hear of this issue? Was there an issue any more important to Canada's economy and our competitiveness than productivity?
April 30, 1992

There was education. There was health. There were implications of many, many government initiatives. There was competitiveness itself. Yesterday we had a moment to take note of what I gather was the last report of the Economic Council of Canada.
It is sad to see it there, but here is the kind of conclusion that an independent agency is prepared to give to this government. Keep in mind and ask yourself whether or not a government ministry would give its minister this kind of advice.
Here is the conclusion. It is on the issue of education and training in Canada, a subject of critical importance to our future. "Without special efforts to develop the requisite skills, Canada's prosperity is in danger. We must forge strong links amongst stakeholders in our learning system, agree upon goals and strive to achieve them. The need for action is urgent, change takes time and we still have a lot to learn". That is the synthesis of the conclusion of that report.
Let us take a look at some of the advice that we got in the report. This is a summary. Some of it hits rather hard at the state of Canada's education and training system. We should take note that the education and training system in Canada is not primarily a federal responsibility. It is a provincial responsibility.
We in this House do not think for a moment that we can sit here oblivious to deficiencies in our education and training system. The report says: "By the year 2000,"-this is a target that it wants government to adopt-"all 16-year old Canadians, except for those who are mentally disabled, should be functionally literate and numerate". That sounds pretty reasonable to me.
Let us take a look at the current status in Canada. In 1989, some 28.5 per cent of 16-year to 24-year-olds did not reach functional literacy. That is 28.5 per cent, level 4 and 44.5 per cent did not reach what they call the numeracy level 3. That is almost half of our youth. They are 16-year to 24-year-olds. That is a shocker, and there it is as a statistic.
Here is another current status. This is bad news, and it had to be made known to government. Full-time college enrolments in engineering and applied sciences have fallen steadily since 1983. Typically fewer than one-fourth of senior high school students enrol in advanced mathematics and science. Full-time college enrolments in engineering and applied sciences have fallen for the
Government Orders
last eight years, since 1983. What has been happening for the last eight years?
This is scary stuff. I thought our education system was improving. I thought we were getting more kids into school. I thought we had more degrees coming out of school. I thought we had more engineers, but we do not. The number is falling. This is a serious problem and this agency has brought this to our attention.
As we work in this particular field as an example with this agency, the Economic Council of Canada, giving us this kind of advice, we are not talking about bingo halls and gambling casinos as an economic entity. They are actually talking about our future intellectual wealth, the competence of our children and our grandchildren. Our ability to prosper economically in the future is going to be totally dependent domestically and internationally on the ability of today's youth in a literate, numerate and skilled way to address those challenges. That is the kind of advice this government is getting. The advice is objective.
Just as an example, what public servant is going to go public with a statement like this? This is in the same report. On page 3 of the summary "Education and Training in Canada", this is crisp stuff: "This is a sign of failure. If current trends continue we will add to the labour force in the next 10 years at least another million young people who will have less than full functional literacy and/or numeracy. This is a sign of failure".
Ministers of education across this country do not want to hear that this is a sign of failure. You will not get published out of any of those provincial ministries or any of the federal ministries because the minister just will not say it that way. He will not say: "We have a failure". He will say: "We have a challenge". They will not publicly admit that there has been a failure, that all of the billions we spend is not achieving the standards that we all seek as Canadians.
That kind of advice from the Economic Council of Canada, just like all of the other agencies, is telling the boss like it is. Maybe the minister is not the boss. Maybe it is the taxpayers that are the boss. That is who is getting told this by these independent agencies which publish their work publicly. They do not just give it to the minister and government and bury it. It is public. They are telling it like it is. We are not learning about it translated through the government press release or the

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
green paper, which is never going to mention, as I said, the concept of failure. No government wants to admit that it has been a failure.
Last, on that same agency, just for the record, the press release of that report yesterday which I have just adverted to states: "This is the Economic Council of Canada's final policy statement. The council is in the process of winding down its research activities, including publication of some final studies. The council is planning to formally close its doors by the end of June 1992". No more advice, no more public analysis, no more independent study, thank you very much, after 30 years.
Now we are going to streamline, eliminate and liquidate this particular agency and others. I just want to reiterate before I move on to the next agency, and this applies to all of the agencies, why independence is so important. The message that they bring to the public is not always good news. There is a lot of bad news to go around out there for everyone. We count on them to tell it like it is. Their product in almost every case is quality.
It is independent and it is not confidential. As I said before, advice to ministers, advice to government is confidential. As a member of Parliament I cannot even see that advice because whenever members on both sides ask the government what advice it got, how it reached that conclusion, it responds that this is advice to the minister, this is advice to the government. It does not talk about it.
If you have ever seen a committee operate and there is a public servant at the committee as a witness and you ask the public servant what advice he gave or what he thinks should be done, the public servant is very constrained and will often have to say he is sorry that it is advice given to the minister. It is for the minister to answer and the public servant cannot tell how he reached his conclusion.
They do their best but under the present system, nada and committees do not usually compel witnesses to provide more information.
The advice given is timely. It is not the government's timing agenda, or the opposition's timing agenda, that these agencies use. It is their own. It is driven by then-own independent assessment of timing and appropriateness. It is driven not by the government's interest but by the public's interest, the people who pay the bills.
In most cases, but not all, the advice and analysis, as I have said, is of critical importance to the future of this country and the direction of government policy.
We have some recent remarks of the chairman of the Economic Council of Canada at a committee because as the public knows the committees review the estimates of government. In the estimates this year there is the statement that we will be chopping, amputating, these agencies.
Here are some of the studies that the chairman of the Economic Council of Canada indicated to the committee that were ongoing. These were just some of them. All five projects are directly focused on the productive capacity of the economy. They include government's impact on competitiveness. That was a reference from the Prime Minister of Canada last year. I would think a reference from the Prime Minister would probably be treated as a top drawer initiative.
Last year it was top drawer. This year, you are out of business. What has changed? We are talking competitiveness here. We are talking the next decade or two of this countiy.
Other ongoing studies include economic relations with the Pacific rim, not an unimportant subject; firm strategy and adaptation, that is corporate and firm economic development strategies on a microeconomic scale I believe, cost effectiveness of the health care system in Canada and human resources strategies at the firm level.
Let us go back to health care. I think we spend about one-third of our provincial budgets on health care. That is certainly the case in the province of Ontario where I am a member. This is a financial issue of extreme importance. I am certain that all Canadians would have benefited and will benefit from the completion of that study if it gets completed.
Ms. Maxwell says that each of these studies will build new knowledge to original in-depth research not being done by any other organization in Canada. The government has asked her to find new homes for these projects so they can be successfully completed. This is evidence or proof that these studies are important but not important enough to keep the agencies alive.
April 30, 1992

"In all cases our sponsors and partners chose to support the projects because they saw the Economic Council as a politically neutral, independent, research organization that could be counted upon to deliver a high quality product". Those are the words of the chairman of one agency and I think the words may be applicable to all or most of the agencies we are discussing here today.
I think our government needs help on all of these issues quite frankly and that is why those agencies are there. In the context of what is happening, it is a little bit like a government, if it were a captain of a ship, throwing off the ship one of its better navigators. However, this navigator is not afraid to tell the captain the truth, not what he wants to hear.
The mandate of the Law Reform Commission of Canada involves an ongoing review of Canadian statutes and makes recommendations for modernization, improvement and reform of Canadian legislation. It has been at work for 22 years and it has developed a lot of work. I practised law for quite few years and I am quite familiar with the work of the Law Reform Commission, as I am sure many colleagues in this House are who work with the reports on the subject areas in law reform. Here are some of the things that it has worked on. It has worked on many. These are just a few: mental disorders in the criminal process and sexual offences. This dates back to 1978-79 when we were beginning to get a handle as a society on the problem of definition of sexual offence in our Criminal Code. The law was 50 or 100 years out of date. The Law Reform Commission broke ground on it. It paved the way to where we are now.
Criteria for determination of death, euthanasia, aiding suicide and the cessation of treatment are issues that have recently been in front of this House, that are before provincial legislatures and will continue to be issues of significance for Canadians.
Turning to re-codifying the Criminal Code, the groundwork was laid back in 1986 and the House of Commons is just now beginning the process of recodification. Who drew the road map? I know who drew it. It was the Law Reform Commission of Canada. That is the
Government Orders
road map we are following now, based on the investment and efforts of that commission many years ago.
Other studies include restitution and compensation; sterilization, implications for mentally retarded and mentally ill persons; extra-territorial jurisdiction that is beyond the international boundaries out into the oceans; electronic surveillance; hate propaganda; crimes against the foetus; plea bargaining, known euphemistically as plea discussions and agreements; and bio-medical experimentation involving human subjects.
I regard these as extremely important subjects for the future of Canadians and maybe even for the human race.
One of the more recent reports was on human dignity and genetic heritage. That is an extremely important issue. Who in this world is looking at the law protecting our genetic heritage as a human species? This is not something I wake up thinking about, this is not something your local police force wakes up thinking about, but the Law Reform Commission has been thinking about it and working on it now for a few years and has begun to publish its report.
This is very sophisticated stuff. The Law Reform Commission is our navigator. This is our road map to protecting the genetic structure of the human race. I am talking about genes, chromosomes. There is a certain amount of genetic tinkering going on around the world. We are all aware of that. It has happened with other animal species, and we are certainly researching and looking at changes in the structure of human chromosomes. We are now working on these issues in laboratories. We have to know. No Canadian law governs it. Research into chromosomes and the genetic structure of human beings in this country is not treated any differently than a grain of salt and that is not right. The Law Reform Commission has begun work on that. That is very valuable. In terms of the gene pool of the human race, all countries had better start working on this immediately.
To abandon the independence of the Law Reform Commission, the timeliness of it, all of the quality work it has done doing is a huge mistake. The Law Reform Commission has generated some 32 reports, 61 working papers and 76 studies. It has been referred to in over 200 significant court judgments. The work of the Law Re-

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
form Commission of Canada has been cited, in particular, in some 39 Supreme Court of Canada decisions.
Where will Canada get its own straight talk on law reform? It is sometimes a difficult issue to get into. Are we going to get it from our friends in the U.S.A., France, the United Kingdom or Germany? Where are we going to get it?
I have to point out that of all Commonwealth countries there are only three that do not have a law reform commission. They are Zimbabwe, Bangladesh, one of the poorest countries in the world and Canada, if we scrap the Law Reform Commission. That is a shame.
The Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security has a mandate to increase knowledge and understanding of the issues relative to international peace and security from a Canadian perspective with particular emphasis on arms control, defence and conflict resolution. We have diplomats all over the world. We have armed forces observers, people all over the world working for Canada. We spend billions of dollars on that. Why can we not spend a modest amount for our navigator, our road map? We cannot afford not to study that area.
The fifth agency is the International Centre for Ocean Development. I have mentioned oceans and the need to study the offshore. We have oceans on three sides of our country.
There is also the Canadian Employment and Immigration Advisory Council. These mandates have been described by the minister. We must ensure that what all of these agencies do continues to be generated in an independent fashion. Nobody wants to make the minister angry.
In closing, the minister has said that there is a cost saving of some $22 million. That was for 46 agencies, not the six we are dealing with. The 46 agencies being chopped yielded $22 million. This is only dealing with six. I suggest that it is not a cost savings.
I submit that we need the direction, reform, competitiveness, initiative and leadership these agencies provided and that is what we want.
Our other critics will be speaking with more precision about these agencies. I submit that this initiative strikes at the heart of efforts of Canadians to provide better government under the guise of simply saving money. I
submit that we are penny wise and pound foolish and we will not support it.
In closing, I would like to move an amendment as follows:
I move:
That the motion be amended by deleting all of the words after the
word "That" and by substituting the following therefor:
Bill C-63, an act to dissolve or terminate certain corporations and other bodies, be not now read a second time, but that it be read a second time this day six months hence.

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as I listened to the minister speak this morning I thought that we really should designate this minister as the minister of grave digging.
This is a gratuitous, unfair, unthought-through decision to buiy six important agencies of the people of Canada. The minister got up this morning and pronounced the words over their graves. As he went through his description of why each of these agencies could be buried we might have expected, as is common in funerals, a little recognition of how important a role has been played, not just for the people of Canada but for this government and its policy activities, by the very agencies that are being attacked and buried with this piece of legislation.
For instance, one might have expected that when the minister talked about the Economic Council he would say: "Well, yes we thought the Economic Council was just tremendous when it came out with its very positive analysis of the free trade deal". The Prime Minister used to quote day after day after day the Economic Council saying that there would be 500,000 extra jobs from the free trade deal. There was not any indication then from this government that the Economic Council was somehow a body that should be buried, that the Economic Council was an organization which did not contribute to this country, because the Economic Council at that time was saying things the government liked.
The same thing is true of the Science Council. When the government party was in opposition before 1984 the Science Council used to come out with some quite critical attacks on the government of the day for not emphasizing science policy, for not emphasizing the importance of investment in research and development in this country. Members of the opposition party then,
April 30, 1992

now the government, would get up in the House and lovingly quote the Science Council of Canada.
There was somehow no memory this morning of those great days of the Science Council when it came time to dig the grave to bury these institutions.
One would have at least expected a little common decency on the part of a government which has made use of these institutions when it could and when it suited its purposes. Now that these institutions are, as independent institutions do, coming out with things that the government does not appreciate the government's answer is: "We will bury these institutions. We will do away with them". It is not because there is any significant saving to the Treasury of this government but because the messenger in this case is bringing messages which this government is not prepared to hear.
The messenger is bringing messages about the reality across this country which has been created by the repeated failures of this government.
This is an exercise in vengeance on the part of this government. It is a scorched earth policy of destruction of the institutions that can help to rebuild this country when we finally get rid of this inept government on the other side of the aisle. Those institutions will not be there to help in the rebuilding of this country; to help to do something about the economic problems, the failures in science policy, the failures in fisheries policy, and the failures in legal reform. Those failures are so clear when you look at the government's record.
Those institutions are not going to be there to help those of us who will have to rebuild after this government is thrown out in the next election. It is not going to be possible because this government is adopting a scorched earth policy of destroying what it can. It is destroying those institutions that are not going to stroke the government and say to it: "You are wonderful". It is destroying those institutions that are going to call it as it is, that are going to see the truth and announce the truth to people across this country.
The Economic Council of Canada, which is the biggest of the institutions being buried today, is an institution
Government Orders
that this government used to love. This government loved it so much that last year the Prime Minister of this country got up and gave a special reference, and special money to go with it, to this important crucial institution, as he put it, to do a full-scale study of competitiveness in this country. What happens a year later? This same government gets up and says: "This government has decided that this institution is no longer needed".
If it was needed a year ago to do a major piece of research work which has not been completed, which the Prime Minister of this country said was essential for the future of this country, that tells us one of two things. Either the Prime Minister was totally incompetent in his decision making last year in assessing the Economic Council of Canada as a body that could do good work in this area, or the Prime Minister and his government are totally incompetent this year in deciding to do away with this very institution.
It does not make sense for a government to change its views so quickly unless the reality is that these institutions have in each case made criticisms, non-partisan criticisms because these institutions knew that at any stage the government could bury them. Therefore, they came out with tempered, careful criticism attempting to point out to the government that the approaches being taken in certain areas were simply not correct.
What did the government decide to do? It decided not just to attack these institutions, to bury them, but to do so to ensure that the governments which must inherit the mess this Conservative regime has created in this country will not be able to call on the help and expertise of these bodies, that in many cases have existed in this country for 20 or 30 years.
They have provided advice, sound disinterested nonpartisan advice, to governments of different stripes. Now this decision is taken in an act of petty vengeance, through a policy of scorched earth destruction of institutions before these guys get booted out. This is a policy which led to the little sermon over the gravestone the minister from the Treasury Board gave us this morning.

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
What is sad about this decision is threefold. First, this government is playing on anti-intellectualism. It is saying: "These are people who think, these are people who do research work. My goodness that must not be worth anything. We are going to get rid of them".
The government is hoping that its red-neck constituents in parts of the country who are deserting it to go to the even more red-neck Reform Party will somehow be attracted back by this sort of red-neck attitude, this red-neck approach which says: "If an institution thinks then buiy it. If an institution has thoughtful criticism then kill it. An institution might help our country better think through its future but we do not want to think about our future. We have easy answers. You do not have to think. All we need is an anti-intellectual response, bury them, kill them, put them six feet under so they cannot be used by the opposition when it comes into government to help rebuild this country". That is the first problem.
The second problem is that this kind of approach gives a bad name to economizing. If the Minister of Finance had really wanted to come into this House of Commons and take some serious steps to economize he would have looked at the fact that we have the biggest cabinet in Canadian history. He would have eliminated ministers and the number of limousines that go with those ministers instead of eliminating important institutions.
We all know ministers in this government do not think. Institutions do. I suspect that if we had two-thirds the number of ministers that we have in the present government we would have saved a great deal of money and probably would have saved ourselves from a lot of serious mistakes. There would be two kinds of benefits to the country.
More seriously perhaps, there are institutions which deserve to be eliminated. Of the six that are part of this legislation I think from what information I have that the elimination of the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council makes sense. I think that is a good step to take. It is not an institution providing something valuable to our country.
When lumping that institution with the other five, any sort of assessment of that particular advisory council is lost in the fact that one is engaged in an over-all active vengeance, a policy of scorching the earth and destroying institutions. This has nothing to do with trying to improve our country's economic situation.
I suggest that even the minister should be here to hear this. Perhaps even the Leader of the Opposition might find useful some of the points which are being put here because the Leader of the Opposition in his cabinet days was responsible for eliminating many institutions thoughtlessly too.
It is important that we recognize if there is going to be a serious assessment of institutions created by government, a serious assessment of ministries, a serious assessment of the number of cabinet ministers who should be in the next government, then there should be some kind of independent review.
There was no such independent review with respect to any of these institutions. We asked the heads of these institutions and we will probe them more carefully when this reaches legislative committee.
We asked them: "Was there any discussion with you? Was there any review of what your institution is doing by independent groups?" There was no such independent review. There was just a decision to eliminate, to cut, to bury and to destroy.
This is not just the view of the New Democratic Party. This is the view of every independent observer who has looked at these institutions. There are the people, for instance, who have looked at the Law Reform Commission like the president of the Canadian Bar Association who said: "I have had it reported to me by some sources that the Law Reform Commission was too independent."
I bridle at that because I do not believe there is such a thing as being too independent.

Mr. Michel Massicotte, president of the Association des avocats de la defense de Montreal, said that in its latest budget, the federal government decided to wind up an institution whose relevance to the Canadian judiciary system was recognized by all, and I am referring to the Law Reform Commission of Canada. He felt that the decision, ostensibly a money-saving measure, was entirely unjustified.

One can hear the same thing for institution after institution. The Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, for instance, is another institute which had made an independent criticism recently of the government's decision to jump ship from those other countries in the international economy, to jump ship and
April 30, 1992

decide to make an early recognition of some of the eastern European countries.
This institute came out with some criticism of that approach. Christopher Young, writing in The Ottawa Citizen, said: "This is not the kind of stuff we hear from the Department of External Affairs".
The same thing is true of the Economic Council. For instance, we can hear from one of those very private institutions that the minister this morning said would somehow take up the slack from the Economic Council.
Michael McCracken, the president of Informetrica, said the council is indispensable for its ability to assign teams of economists to big projects. University researchers and private sector firms cannot mount the long-term large projects that the council undertook.
What we have here is a destructive, unjust, unfair, unthinking approach on the part of the government. It is scorched earth policy to make things hard for the future, for the government which will replace these inept people on the government side who do not recognize the importance of thought, the importance of analysis, and the importance of independence from these institutions which they are trying to destroy in this legislation before us today.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to comment.
I listened as I always do to my hon. friend from Essex-Windsor. I must say to him that if this was the debating club of the London School of Economics in the 1920s under Harold Laski, I might even think some of what he said made sense.
I am absolutely appalled to sit in this House and hear this gentleman refer to my constituents as a bunch of rednecks and to suggest that the members on this side are anti-intellectual. I cannot help but shake my head and I have an understanding.
When he talks about the fact that this government is going to be replaced I understand why the people of Canada have alternated between the members on this side and the members of the now Official Opposition to
Government Orders
govern this country and for 60 years have rejected the philosophy that he trumpets in this place today.
When he makes comments like he has just made about the people of Canada, about the people I have the privilege to represent here, he comes across in my judgment as nothing but an arrogant, sanctimonious fool, and on behalf of them I say that.
This bill, this budgetary decision, has absolutely nothing to do with vengeance or mean-spirited closing down critics of the government, as he suggests.
What were his views when the Economic Council of Canada so thoroughly endorsed the free trade proposals of this government? Did he get up and laud that decision? Did he accept the wisdom of that advice? That is not my recollection.
Is it not interesting? These agencies from time to time have criticized the government and from time to time have endorsed the government. Politicians on both sides have taken advantage when it suits their purposes and that is the essence of partisan politics I suppose.
This government has consistently followed a philosophy which I think is clearly endorsed by the people of Canada when it comes to thinking about the taxpayer, when it comes to thinking about the need to rationalize redundant institutions.
There are some here who think that once a program is established it is supposed to be there forever, even when it is not needed any more. It is the same with institutions.
What this bill is about and what the budgetary measure that it reflects is about is recognizing that times change, recognizing that as needs are fulfilled in the private sector there is no longer a need to burden the taxpayer with the cost of those measures. That is why this government is being responsive to the taxpayer when it gets rid of agencies that are redundant.
Take the area of economics of which my hon. friend speaks. There are a multiplicity of agencies providing that kind of research for the people of Canada. We have the Conference Board of Canada, the Institute for Research on Public Policy, the C. D. Howe Institute, the Fraser Institute which are now fulfilling that purpose. Why should we burden the taxpayer with the cost of those other institutions when in fact the services are

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
being provided elsewhere? I guess I should bring myself to a question for my hon. friend. I have two questions.
First, will he stand in his place and apologize to the people of Canada that he has insulted with his remarks earlier today? I am sure he did not mean what he said.
Second, will he stand in his place and assure Canadians that the New Democratic Party does not believe that the taxpayers should be burdened by funding redundant institutions or paying for services that are no longer required?

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
A remarkable performance, Madam Speaker. An arrogant, sanctimonious fool. I throw the accusation back and we will see who wears it best.
It seems to me that what has to be recognized first by this member and by this government is that the institutions that are being eliminated are institutions which were working to reduce costs in this country.
The Economic Council for instance, which is costing taxpayers about $10 million a year, has the responsibility to reduce health care costs in this country. It is carrying out a major study to do this. The Economic Council has a good track record. It has come up with some important research suggestions and conclusions.
I dare to suggest that there would be much more saved by permitting the Economic Council to carry through on its study of how to reduce health care costs in this country, rather than bury the Economic Council.
The member has suggested that the private sector can do these various things. Of course, there are institutions across this country in the private sector, each of them with an axe to grind: the Fraser Institute grinds its axe on the right-hand side; the Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives grinds its axe on the left-hand side. We could leave policy debate in this country to people with special interests.
The important point of these institutions is that they came at things from an independent perspective. That independent perspective is what is crucial if we are going to come up with real answers for the future economic problems that we face in this country.
I want to deal with one last point which the hon. member raised. He suggested that I was making some comments about the people of Canada. Not in the least. The people of Canada have shown without question in
poll after poll after poll that they want to get rid of this government. That demonstrates the supreme common sense of the people of Canada, the supreme common sense which says that fewer than 10 per cent of people in this country approve of the Prime Minister and his policies. I applaud the people of Canada for their astuteness in seeing this.
What I find absolutely frustrating and saddening is in trying to deal with this situation of unpopularity, this situation of failure demonstrated by this government that it has tried to appeal not to people across the board in this country but instead to that small sector of people who think that the solution to our problems is to get rid of those institutions which are doing the thinking, which are caring about the future, which are doing analysis. It has tried instead to appeal to that small red-neck minority that thinks if we can get rid of any government institution it is a good thing.
I have said that it makes sense to get rid of one of these institutions because I do not think it is doing a good job. However the other five are doing important work in this country. For our party and I think I also speak for the people of Canada in saying this, important work in looking to the future is something which should be supported, not buried as this minister is trying to do.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this morning we are discussing Bill C-63, a piece of legislation that seems quite harmless: just eight pages which contain 46 separate sections. Nothing special.
However, it has been my privilege to serve the Canadian people as a cabinet minister for many years.

When I see this terminator government moving, I really get worried. I have worked in government for a long time. It is throwing everything out. As is said in the English proverb, you are throwing out the baby with the bath water. This is the case. We agree that some of the things on this long list have to go. Many of them were established by the Tories. The extravagant Minister of National Defence has created committee after committee. Of course these committees have to go and him too.
April 30, 1992

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
However, on that list we know are some institutions that are very important to the very fabric of this country. To terminate them is a big mistake and is why I am standing in this House today.
For example, I worked for many years with the Economic Council of Canada when I was minister. It criticized the government. It said to us many times over that we were not right here and we were not right there. It made recommendations that we did not accept; but one thing I know is that it was an independent voice, a voice that was created for that purpose, and we listened to it.
I heard the member from Nova Scotia a minute ago saying that he will rely on the Fraser Institute of Vancouver. Who does it represent? It represents big businesses. That is all. It is paid by them and it serves them very well.
We do not have in Canada an institute like the Brookings Institute in the United States that tends to be close to the Democrat Party. They are lucky; they have no New Democrats in the United States. They have the Democrat Party and another institute that is close to the Republican Party. However in Canada we have an institute that is funded by the government. It was founded in 1963.
We have to understand that when it was created there was a purpose. Mr. Pearson created it because he said words to the effect that it was to be a forum where everybody would be represented. Labour, management and social groups were represented there to debate in complete freedom and after that make recommendations. This has been very useful to this government.
Many times-and I have experienced it from these discussions-even if we did not agree with all the conclusions we knew from groups preoccupied with the economic development of the nation what kinds of problems we were faced with and what kinds of solutions we could find.
This is going out now. We can look at all the work it has has done. It was talking about the big problems of prosperity and how to be competitive. These were the words used by Mike Pearson as Prime Minister in 1963 when he proposed that. He used the same terms, that we had to fit Canada into a world of more competition. It was the same thing in 1963 when the government introduced it.
Government Orders
During the period of time before the Tories came to power Canada was pretty good in terms of competition around the world. However, through this instrument that prepared report after report after report Canadians were offered a place of reflection. Every one of us- members of Parliament and people working on political programs-debated those reports. We knew there was a body that was not paid by big businesses, that was not paid by big unions, but was paid to reflect on the problems. It was typical, a Liberal solution.
Big business does not like it. It criticized the government. I know, I have been there, that it is not bad to be criticized sometimes. It is very useful. But this government cannot take it. The Tories cannot take it. If they had listened to the Economic Council of Canada a little more, perhaps they would not have made the big mistake they made to please their big business friends. Now they want all their advice to come from the Fraser Institute. I do not want that. I want to keep that type institution, the Economic Council of Canada. They are worried because the Reform Party is taking votes away from them.
What are they saving by killing all these institutions? Some $20 million. The two helicopters the Minister of National Defence is buying these days would have done the trick. There would have been 98 left. They have a kind of dog and pony show on competitiveness with $20 million. All the money is there. They announced it. A lot of consultants are getting money and we have not seen anything yet from this prosperity agenda they are supposed to sell to Canadians. They only cut back and they do not have to cut the Economic Council of Canada.
What about the Law Reform Commission? I have been Minister of Justice. When it was created in 1970 we realized it was an important instrument. I myself found it helpful on many occasions, for instance when we were working on the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, now part of the Canadian Constitution and a source of pride for all Canadians. We, on this side of the House, made a dream come true, the dream of everyone who thinks in terms of civil liberties in this country. It was also John Diefenbaker's dream to have a Charter of Rights and Freedoms in the Constitution.

The Law Reform Commission has been a great inspiration to us. I could mention all the other studies the commission has produced, covering areas such as evidence, pornography, euthanasia and violence in our society. Right now, it is preparing a study on drugs, sponsored by the Prime Minister a few years ago, when

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
he told Canadians he was going to do something about this problem and that the government was going to deal with it. And now, the only institution that was doing work on the subject is being terminated, if I may use that term for what the government is doing today to an instrument for social progress.
In a society like ours it is very difficult to balance everyone's needs because the problems vary, depending on whether you live in Newfoundland or British Columbia, the Gaspe or Windsor. The people, the problems and the attitudes are not identical.
How do we find a social consensus? It takes people who are dedicated and who are not doing it for political gain but to provide politicians with information. This means we have an instrument that is useful to us as politicians, but also to social workers or university professors or educators as a source of reference points. As a result our society with all its problems is still at the top of the list because we have the courage to look at our own shortcomings, listen to criticism and learn from our mistakes. This government, however, is too proud to ever admit it is wrong. Too bad. It is very healthy to have people who will tell us when we make mistakes. Why get rid of them?
Now take the Science Council of Canada.

What about the future? If we do not invest in research and development, if we do not invest in the brains of the young people of Canada, what will Canada be in the next century? This was an instrument that was helping them.

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext: Hear, hear.

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
We need the courage to invest in the brains of Canadians and the Conservatives scrap it for a few million dollars when they spend money like crazy on all sorts of their own programs, on things like publicity and ads all over Canada all the time.
Of course we know why. It is because there is an expert in communications in the Prime Minister's Office, in giving contracts to advertising companies. That is very important, but it is important to me to keep the Science Council of Canada.
What about medical research, pure research? Let us look at the scientific people in our land who have found their way through working with that, like John Polanyi. They are now cutting the rudder because the ship is too big. That is pretty smart. The ship is just as big but it has no rudder. That is exactly what they are doing today. It is absolutely ridiculous.
It is important that the government look at the money that the Japanese, the Germans and the Americans put into research and development. The Prime Minister said seven years ago that it was to be his priority. It shrank and shrank and shrank on a daily basis. Now the Conservatives conclude by scrapping the Science Council of Canada.
It is the same thing with the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. This is an area wherein the country has tried over years and with very little partisanship, I must admit, to place Canada in a position where we would be respected. We were a middle power and wanted to play a very useful role, and through institutions like that one we could have it all. When we want to develop a non-partisan approach to international relations we have to rely on institutions that everybody can have confidence in. The Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security was created for that reason. It is even more important today because nobody knows where the world is going.
There has been a great change in the world balance in the last 18 months and we see troubles coming from very different sources. Even more today than ever before we will need to reflect on what can be the best position. Canada can be a very good instrument internationally to do that. We were spending a few million dollars on the Canadian Institute for International peace and Security and they scrapped it.
April 30, 1992

When it was introduced not long ago, it was the present Prime Minister who wrote to the Prime Minister of the day telling him it was very important that this agency be neutral. He said that we should not go with the prevailing winds but should make sure that Canada had an original, authentic position in that field. It is what we have always tried to do because we have a great history we are all proud of, starting with the UN Charter, where Mr. St. Laurent and Mr. Pearson were among the architects.
Our minister of external affairs of that time received the Nobel Prize for peace. Canada has developed peacekeeping forces that can play a better role in the future. But we will not have the neutral instruments to convince everybody of new orientations and help us to put aside the partisanship that is natural in politics. This government is killing these agencies for a few million dollars when it is spending money like drunken sailors all over the country.
It has only to keep the Minister of National Defence in Canada once in a while and it will save a lot of money. He just comes here once in a while for refuelling and to cause problems.
We want to tell this government that we object to this bill.

We intend to talk about these things, because what is so disturbing about these developments is that when this government ceases to exist, there will no longer be an instrument that truly represents our country. There is a pattern here. All the opportunities that existed in this country for scientists and researchers and intellectuals to get together and discuss the real problems of our country-and I am not referring to the Constitution, because we are sick and tired of hearing about the Constitution-are disappearing, thanks to this government. We are losing them all, one after another. We no longer have the national railway system that united Canadians. The government is destroying the infrastruc-
Govemment Orders
tures that unite us. We no longer have a symbol of Canada.
The hon. member mentioned the other day that the word Canada no longer appears on our mailboxes. The word Canada seems to have become an embarrassment. The other day, an English-speaking member from Ontario told me that when he wanted some Canadian flags, he would go and see a Conservative member who was too embarrassed to distribute them in his own riding. Now isn't that appalling?
That is how we will lose the country, when we no longer have the courage to maintain institutions where all Canadians can get together, scientists as well as people with a concern for international peace, who are less concerned about whether they are French-speaking or English-speaking than about poverty and the future of our planet. When these people can no longer meet, and this includes the economists who are working through the Economic Council of Canada to find positions for Canada in tomorrow's very complex world and who are trying to find the niche Canadians must have in the 21st century, to have the kind of country we want, all that will disappear. We will be left with advisers who are on the payroll of big corporations and big unions. They will have their say, while the real people of this country will no longer be represented objectively, the way they ought to be.
That is why we object to this legislation. We are all for saving money, and there are many items on this list that can stay there, as far as we are concerned, but why throw out the baby with the bath water, just because the government does not have the guts to choose? Let them provide an objective analysis of every one of these institutions and tell us why the Economic Council of Canada is no good.
The hon. member from Nova Scotia said a few minutes ago that they recommended supporting the free trade agreement. That was a mistake, and the Conservative Party should have seen that.
They made mistakes, but they were only giving an opinion. In all the other fields we need such advisory boards. Personally, in the field of law reform, I know that such a board is necessary because the problems are increasingly difficult. If we do not anticipate them, as the Law Reform Commission is trying to do, we will have

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
serious social problems. Those are the people who are trying to tell us how we in Canada can be more generous than others and how we should have a legal system that enables citizens to obtain justice, regardless of their colour, language or race. If we cannot criticize ourselves, if we cannot listen to people who are paid to criticize us objectively without thinking of scoring political points, the country will suffer.
That is why we object and we ask government members to withdraw this bill. They should take out what is not good and we will vote with them, but the important tools of national unity and social and economic development that existed in the past should continue to exist. That is why I am telling you, Madam Speaker, that we are asking the government to withdraw its bill, do it over and choose between the institutions that are worth keeping and those which are not. Eliminate those that are not, but keep what is important for the country.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I do indeed have a question. I am interested in knowing the Leader of the Opposition's position with respect to fiscal restraint.
I listened with great care to his speech and I know it was certainly on a higher plane than that of the previous speaker. He suggested the government spent like drunken sailors. I suppose he could have been truly insulting and suggested that we spent like Liberals or worse, like New Democrats from Ontario. But he did not do that.
Bill C-63 is responding to what the government believes is a very clear concern on the part of Canadians to have leaner government, to control expenditures.

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext: You are a great example of that.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
I am what I am.
This bill seeks to remove institutions that are redundant. Given that this government believes taxpayers should not be required to pay for agencies and institutions whose services are being provided elsewhere, and that this government has turned the $16 billion operating deficit it received from his government to a $10 billion operating surplus, what is his position with respect to fiscal restraint when he opposes the community consultations? Is he opposing the government consulting with Canadians and does he believe that Canadian taxpayers should be required to pay for institutions that have become redundant or whose functions are being carried out by other agencies?

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, we are responsible. We do not have to take any lessons from these members. We do not control the deficit by killing institutions like those. You have a dog and pony show and prosperity that cost $25 million. It is more than that. I could go through the list.
We can find a lot of places where money was spent for nothing. What is important is that the country functions well. I am happy the hon. member recognizes that what I said made sense. He should look at the list. I am not saying we should keep every one of these institutions. Some have to go. Sunset should exist on a lot of programs we have.
You must remember that at one time I was President of the Treasury Board and my nickname was "Dr. No" because I could cut. I know how it is. Over the years fat develops in administrations and it has to be cut. But do not cut what is good. Do not cut brain power, do not cut what is an investment in the future. That is what we are telling members opposite.
We will applaud them when they will reflect that, but this is a decision of a panicky government which is afraid to choose. If we had heard good arguments that the Economic Council of Canada is no damn good, fine. If they can convince me, we will let it go. If they can find a good argument that the Science Council of Canada is no good, we will listen to that. If they convince me, we will let it go. If they can convince me that the Law Reform Commission of Canada is redundant, I will listen to them.
I was a minister for many years and very often I was not happy with the reports I received. After thinking about it, I know that these reports reflected a point of
April 30, 1992

view that was not partisan and which the agencies went out to search for, having different people from different parts of Canada discuss these things for months. Even if it was hurtful, I thought it was useful.
It is the Canadian way of doing things. We should not copy the Americans all the time. We like them very much but a lot of the things they do we do not want for Canada.
I do not want the Fraser Institute or the CLC producing reports telling us what to do. It is not what I want. I am a Liberal. I want to do things the Canadian way, by consensus, searching out the answers from people who you know are not part of your political belief.
Take medical research or any of the other items they are cutting. These are probably the things that make Canadians feel comfortable about themselves. If there is a problem in law, we send it to the Law Reform Commission. Lawyers come from all across the land to debate the problem. Suddenly they realize that we have Canadian values.
When you want to have a good Canadian meeting about medical research, you gather together doctors and medical research people from across the land. They talk about research, and how Canadians can do it better than anyone else. They do not talk about the Constitution in the French and English languages. They try to find a Canadian way to do things better than anyone else, including the Americans. That is what we want for Canada. We want to make Canada the best.
It is not in killing these good institutions that Canada will be where it should be, number one.
