Mr. Speaker, I rise today to once again express my support for our country, Canada. Only a united Canada continues to be the best place in the world. I do so by echoing the comments of the Prime Minister in his speech in Hull, Quebec, recently in which he introduced some sobering facts to the unity debate.
Those who wish to divide this great nation or misunderstand the consequences of division will accuse him of economic terrorism or overstatement. I think not. We will all surely suffer socially and economically if Canada is divided.
I say that to the people and leaders of all regions and, in particular, to the new premier of Saskatchewan. Nation building means learning to compromise. It means looking for ways to make the country work. It means positive thinking.
I am saddened when I hear Saskatchewan's premier say he will not put his name to any constitutional agreement just to keep Canada together. As well, I ask the people and leaders of Quebec to please be willing to give a little. The reality is we cannot have any of the comforts of marriage after our divorce.
April 30, 1992

Let us not be fooled. Let us not be misled.

Mr. Speaker, the International Labour Organization will be holding its annual meeting in Geneva starting on June 3.
Several conventions will be under consideration. One in particular, No. 147, deals with the standards of work for employees of merchant ships and included, of course, are Canadian seamen.
I urge the Minister of Labour to ratify this convention on behalf of Canada as well as the several others that deal specifically with the welfare and safety of Canadian workers. This is long overdue and I urge that this be done at the earliest possible convenience.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ken James (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Labour):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Labour
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to inform this House of the launching of the Canadian code of practice for consumer debit card services which will take place in Toronto on May 1.
The development of the code is a positive step forward in consumer protection. It also provides a flexible and effective alternative to separate federal and provincial regulations. It is an excellent example of the partnership theme of National Consumer Week, namely, "It's Everybody's Business".
The code sets out provisions to protect consumers who use debit cards at automated banking machines and point of sale terminals. It will apply throughout Canada offering the same level of protection to consumers wherever they live.
The code was drafted by business, consumer, and government representatives. This initiative has demonstrated the benefits of partnership and consultation between government and affected interest groups.

[Editor's Note: Member spoke in Inuktituk.]
On Monday, May 4, residents of the Northwest Territories will vote in a plebiscite on a boundary line to divide the NWT into two parts. The Inuit of the eastern Arctic have lead the drive toward division so they can have a government which is closer to them.
Right now people on Baffin Island in the extreme east of the existing Northwest Territories are situated north of the province of Quebec. Yet they have to deal with a territorial capital located in Yellowknife which is north of Alberta. No other Canadian citizens have to deal with a provincial or territorial capital which is two time zones away.
Division will lead to two new territories: Nunavut in the eastern Arctic and Denendeh in the western Arctic, each more responsive to the needs of its people and able to contribute more strongly to this great country.
In this 125th anniversary year for Canada we are on the verge of welcoming a new partner to our federation.
The people of Nunavut are ready and I urge the residents of the Northwest Territories to vote yes in favour of the boundary.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to mention Murray Maltais's editorial in Le Droit today on the speech that the Prime Minister gave to the Outaouais Chamber of Commerce on Tuesday. "By speaking out publicly on the risks that western Quebec runs on the constitutional issue, the Prime Minister is contributing to greater recognition of its particular status in Quebec and in Canada, whether we agree with the line of argument chosen or not".
On that occasion, the Prime Minister mentioned, among other things, the actual situation of the Ottawa area, which is highly vulnerable with the federal government as the driving force of the economy.

April 30, 1992
The region, Quebec and all of Canada are indebted to him for his frankness on the vital issues.

Mr. Speaker, to many World War II is synonymous with the horrors of the Holocaust.
Today marks the observance of Yom Ha Shoah, a day of remembrance for all those who died as a result of the Nazi firing squads and death camps. Within 12 years of Adolph Hitler coming to power over 6 million Jews from Germany, Poland and all over Europe were senselessly and brutally slaughtered.
They died not because they were soldiers on one side or the other, but simply because they were Jewish. Their deaths serve to remind us of the horror that can result from racial intolerance.
Racism is not dead. It continues to rear its ugly head in many forms throughout Canada and around the world. Its sting is felt most by our visible minorities and those least able to defend themselves.
Today, we must remember the past and work together to eliminate all forms of racism from our lives.

Mr. Speaker, to celebrate Canada's 125th birthday the Edmonton Symphony Society developed a patriotic program entitled; "Made in Canada". They submitted this proposal to the Canada 125 Corporation for review but bureaucrats refused to take it to the Canada 125 board for consideration, effectively killing the proposal.
Rather than work with the symphony to discuss their concerns and to improve the proposal, the corporation chose to kill it. For three weeks I have placed calls to the co-chair, Frank King, and have heard nothing but silence.
Edmonton is the fifth largest metropolitan area in Canada and as such the proposal deserves to be considered.
I call upon Canada 125 to work with the Edmonton Symphony to develop a great program to celebrate the accomplishments of Canadian composers and musicians.

Mr. Speaker, the Leader of the Bloc Quebecois and union leaders met in Montreal yesterday on the occasion of workers' day. The union leaders clearly stated that the debate must be on the costs of federalism and that the onus is on the federalists, who since 1980 have promised to settle the constitutional question and economic issues.
The Bloc Quebecois undertook to demand that the free trade agreement with the United States and Mexico include transitional provisions, a social charter and an environmental charter. The bloc also promised to press for an anti-scab law at the federal level, and the present lockout at Nationair proves how urgent such a law is.
While the Prime Minister attacks unionized workers, at the same time as he frequents private clubs, the bloc, the large labour organizations and Quebec workers are just waiting for the opportunity to say yes to sovereignty in the Quebec referendum in October 1992.

Mr. Speaker, during the week of May 3 to 9 we will be celebrating National Forest Week. The 1992 theme is: "Take a closer look".
We are all becoming more conscious of the rich resources we have at our disposal. At the present time, approximately 1 million Canadian workers depend on the forest industry. Yet with so many Canadians depending on our forests for their survival, we see major funding cuts in forest resource development agreements. These cuts will result in a 25 per cent reduction in planting in the north central region of Ontario this year.
April 30, 1992

During National Forest Week the question every Canadian should be asking himself or herself is: "How can I help to make our forests better and more productive?"
One method to improve this important natural resource would be through better educational programs that support the concept of the model forest.

Mr. Speaker, the media has been inflaming negative feelings toward Quebec by reporting only the business contracts awarded to Quebec companies and neglecting to report business contracts awarded to companies in other provinces.
At a time when all Canadians are being asked to put aside petty differences, the press seems to think that it is more important to fan the flames of division rather than to promote unity.
Government contracts are awarded to all provinces. It seems strange that we have to defend only the contracts awarded to Quebec and not the contracts going to other regions of Canada. Quebec contracts become front page news and require cabinet ministers to rise in the House of Commons in defence of them.
I do not like the implications of this. As far as I am concerned, it is completely unacceptable and un-Canadian. The press must start behaving in a responsible manner giving Canadians the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth.

Mr. Speaker, once again, the government has chosen to ignore New Brunswick's problems. Today it decided to penalize Sackville, a town already affected by high unemployment. Now-.

The government is closing down the RCMP crime lab in Sackville and 30 jobs will be lost. That is the equivalent of 5,000 jobs in Ottawa. It has done it without advising the mayor and without even having the courtesy to inform the member of Parliament for Beausejour.
I would like to ask the government to review that decision and make sure that the economics of these problems are being reviewed and that justice be done for the city of Sackville.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the news today is unfortunately true that a former Socred politician is in Washington, D.C. paid for by U.S. lumber interests to argue against Canada's position on the softwood lumber tariff.
It is an indication of how desperate the Americans are in this dispute against Canada. The key to resolving this dispute is for our own government to hold firm and not sell out like it did in 1986 when it signed the softwood lumber tariff memorandum of understanding.
Despite the growing number of trade disputes between Canada and the U.S., the federal government is telling us that free trade will save us. Most Canadians just do not believe that.
Since the Prime Minister will be in Washington, D.C. on May 20 when the next softwood decision is to be made, we call on the government to deliver the strongest message possible to the U.S. that our forests are Canada's and it is not for the United States to dictate to us how to run them.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on Monday, the government announced a $1 billion sole source contract to Bell Helicopter in Quebec and there has been a great hue and cry.
At the same meeting of cabinet a $900 million sole source contract was awarded to a London, Ontario firm to provide LAVs. There were the same rules but a different province and nobody, it would seem, has paid any attention.
Last year, a $1 billion high-tech military contract was awarded to an Alberta company yet not a peep did we hear from the Reform Party about that. Not so long ago, the largest military contract in Canadian history, $4.7 billion was sole sourced to Saint John Shipbuilding in New Brunswick and nobody in Atlantic Canada complained.

April 30, 1992
Oral Questions
The Bell decision was the right decision. No other Canadian company was prepared to bid on or fulfil the contract. The Mirabel company was the only one that could supply what the Canadian Armed Forces said it needed. The contract will be good for Canadian defence, it will be good for Quebec workers and it will be good for Canada.

Mr. Speaker, the news yesterday out of Edmonton is that the federal government and the provinces have reached an agreement in principle for a social covenant in the Constitution. We must commend them for that. What they are saying is that the principles of the negotiations are the five principles included in the parliamentary report on the renewal of Canada.
The five principles include: enshrining the basic principles of medical care in the Constitution; protecting the social services such as housing in the Constitution of Canada; providing protection for not only elementary school education but also secondary and post-secondary education; protecting the rights of workers to organize and bargain collectively; and finally, preserving the integrity of the environment in the Constitution of Canada.
I understand the details are still to be worked out, but we must commend the leaders of our provincial governments and the federal government for making sure that this is now approved to go into the Constitution of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, the recent controversy over the awarding of a helicopter contract to a Quebec firm has been a good news story for those who want to divide Canada.
Where were these agents of division when Ontario received the $1 billion contract for vehicles, or the $1 billion contract that went to Alberta for communications equipment, or the $4 billion contract that went to New Brunswick? If the critics want to tell the story, I believe
they should tell the whole story and they should tell the truth. As the hon. member for Halton-Peel said yesterday, Canada is not a balance sheet.
I urge all Canadians to stop looking at contracts going to Quebec as being somehow different from those going to other parts of Canada.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of Finance.
Earlier this month we learned that 74,000 people lost their jobs in the month following the budget. Today we learned that 7,000 people and businesses went bankrupt in that same month, the month of March.
It is obvious that the federal budget is not working and now everyone is shaking in their boots about what Pink Floyd is going to do in Ontario today.
Will the Minister of Finance do something to kick-start the economy? It is very evident that there has been no growth since the budget, that all the projections he made are not true, and that the economy needs some help to start again. Will the minister review his bad judgment of two months ago?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I share the concern of the hon. Leader of the Opposition. I am certainly not comforted. In fact I am disturbed by the bankruptcy figures and I am not comforted by the level of unemployment.
In fairness the hon. Leader of the Opposition should recognize that the budget was brought down on February 25. The figures we are dealing with today show there has been a modest pick up in GDP in the month of February. There has been a modest pick up in the month of January. As a matter of fact, Statistics Canada adjusted those figures upward. We see the bankruptcy figures for March as being very disturbing, but I think the hon. member would recognize that it does take a little time for the initiatives of the budget to take hold.
April 30, 1992

I remind the hon. member that we did act on the manufacturing and processing side. We did act in terms of stimulating the housing sector. I firmly believe, given the level of interest rates, the fact that there has been moderation in interest rates by more than seven percentage points since the high of May 1990, the fundamentals and the components for sustainable growth and recovery are clearly there.
We should also be pleased about the fact that it seems the American economy has indeed turned around. It has shown a two percentage point increase in GDP in the first quarter and I think that augurs well for Canada.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this week I was in Quebec, which in March registered nearly 500 new business bankruptcies. The exact number was 471, which is more than in any other province.
If you walk down the streets of Montreal, you see empty shop windows with signs reading "For Rent" or "For Sale". One gets the impression that the only business flourishing in Montreal is the one making these signs.
I would like to put the following question to the minister. I met the mayor of Montreal who told me that if the government accepted the proposal made in the House by the Liberal Party-a proposal made previously by municipalities-to finance one-third of the cost of building city infrastructures, Montreal and the mayor of Montreal could put hundreds of thousands of people to work as early as next week or next month on useful and lasting projects. This is not about buying groceries but about building the infrastructures Montreal and other Canadian cities so desperately need.
Why will the minister not agree to a proposal that would only cost him one-third of the total cost? He would recover a large part of his investment, people would go back to work and the economy would take a turn for the better.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. Leader of the Opposition knows that in addition to the economy
Oral Questions
being weak we have been going through a major industrial restructuring.
The budget tried to identify that, tried to assist and improve the climate of industry, and tried to assist and improve the climate of investment so that this restructuring process could be facilitated.
I am pleased that many of the provinces have been complementary in their budgets. They have brought in policies that are complementary. I only hope the Government of Ontario brings down a budget today that will be complementary to strengthening and enhancing the manufacturing and processing sector.
I think that is really important. I am sure he would agree with me that it is in that particular area the real decline in unemployment and the real impact of the restructuring and the slowing down of the economy have been effected mostly.
He suggests that we should engage in a spending program. The hon. Leader of the Opposition knows that the federal government does not have the fiscal capacity to do what he is asking us to do. I doubt very much that the provinces have the fiscal capacity.
He is really saying: "Drive up the deficit or tax more in order to create some jobs". While I am sympathetic, I think he recognizes that in order for us to lay the groundwork for sustainable growth with price stability we have to contain inflation and we have to consolidate our fiscal problem. That is what we are doing.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Finance will understand very easily that if he put $1 billion on the table the provinces will put $1 billion on the table, as they have agreed, and the municipalities will do the same. He will get back a lot of money in taxes, less unemployment insurance and welfare payments. He will recuperate almost 80 per cent of his investment.
At the same time there will be hope in Canada because the people will be circulating in the cities and they will see people working. After that they will have confidence to spend their money to help the economy.
Will the minister not accept such a proposition? It will not cost him a lot of money. It will create jobs and hope in the country.

April 30, 1992
Oral Questions
Hear, hear.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I see hon. members applauding that.
The Leader of the Opposition is saying: "Go out and borrow $3 billion and spend it and you will get $3 billion worth of taxes back". If the hon. Leader of the Opposition has that figured out, I would like to see how he does that calculation.
The fact of the matter is that there is only one taxpayer. Taxpayers are fed up with taxes at the federal level, at the provincial level, and at the municipal level.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
Last month in Ontario alone there were almost 3,000 bankruptcies, the highest number in all of Canada. That means that in Ontario in the first full month after the minister's budget nearly 100 people and businesses went bankrupt each and every day. That is each and every day. No wonder Canadians are fed up with this government. These are not just numbers. They represent lost jobs, lost hopes and dreams.
Why can the minister not recognize this? Why does he not take action before more time is lost? Why does he not take action to stop this economic destruction and help get Canadians working again?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I share the hon. member's concern about the loss of jobs, the loss of dreams, and the fact that businesses have been lost.
I think he also recognized that a major restructuring has been going on in the retail sector and that many of the bankruptcies have been effected in the retail sector. That has occurred not only here but in the United States as well.
He condemns the budget because within a month it did not turn everything around. The budget was not designed to turn the economy around in one month. It was designed to deal with the very basic and fundamental problems, the structural problems, and to aid in that process.
We targeted the manufacturing and the processing sector. We targeted the housing sector. We continued our effort to maintain a macro-economic policy geared toward sustainable growth and price stability, attacking inflation and consolidating the deficit.
If the hon. member is asking that we drive up the deficit, spend more money and try to spend our way out of this, I can tell him that is not an option as far as I am concerned.

Mr. Speaker, Canadians, members on this side of the House and I are asking the government to do something to help the one and a half million Canadians without work find jobs.
I want to ask a question of the Minister of Employment and Immigration. In the first month after the budget, in addition to some 7,000 more bankruptcies, 74,000 people lost their jobs across Canada. Surely this cannot be the economic recovery, the restoration of fundamentals his colleague the Minister of Finance keeps talking about.
What is the Minister of Employment and Immigration going to do to help stop this economic destruction and create jobs now for the one and a half million Canadians without work who want help from this government, not just more empty talk?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will tell the hon. member and colleagues in the House that the UI program reacted rapidly to the deteriorating labour market condition.
Some $17 billion of income support to UI claimants have helped the people who have to go through these economic times. In this fiscal year we have increased by $300 million training funds so that we can help those individual Canadians.
The Liberal Party calls for us to buy the illusion of prosperity by throwing money at it, money that taxpayers do not have. The Minister of Finance has put the case clearly.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance as well.
The bank rate has gone up by 12 basis points today, a significant increase. Does the Minister of Finance not recognize that this increase in the bank rate is a danger-
April 30, 1992

ous signal to consumer confidence across the country and to business confidence across the country?
Will he admit that part of the reason for the bank rate to increase is the minister's own irresponsible comments before the G-7 meeting in Washington this weekend during which he shocked people across the international business community by talking about the future of interest rates in a way a Minister of Finance should never speak at an international situation?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was only using the communique that was produced by the G-7 finance ministers which said that real interest rates remain high. Ministers were of the view that satisfactory progress on inflation, curbing excessive wage pressure, and progress in consolidating fiscal positions would create the basis for lower interest rates.
That is exactly the thrust of the comments that I made, which is consistent with the conclusions of the G-7 finance ministers.

Mr. Speaker, the minister in fact said that Canadian rates were going to decrease. That has created a crisis, some lack of confidence, and the minister should be prepared to admit it.
However, I want to ask the minister not just about that increase in bank rates but about the tragic increase in bankruptcies that has taken place. We have had a higher level of bankruptcies announced today than in any previous month in Canadian history. One of the victims is Gary Bilmes of Windsor who has worked for 15 years for Maher Shoes-
I think I must ask the hon. member to get to the close of his question.

Mr. Speaker, my question is this: What has the minister to say to Gary Bilmes who is one of 700 people in Maher Shoes who have lost their jobs across this country? Cannot the minister see that his policies are failing?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, what I have said in the House and outside the House on many occasions is that with the progress this government has made on inflation and on fiscal consolidation, we have witnessed a
Oral Questions
reduction in interest rates by more than seven percentage points since the high of May 1990.
I think it is fair to say with the continuing record that is being followed in this regard, which is consistent with our macro-economic policies, it provides scope for further interest rate reductions because of the low rate of inflation. That is not something I have strayed away from because it is part and parcel of the fundamental policy that is adopted by this government. It has been echoed as well by the Governor of the Bank of Canada. That is what is said and nothing more.
In so far as his reference to an individual, of course I am sympathetic, but I also advise the hon. member that it is important for us to get the fundamentals right. The basis for a solid recovery, the basis for sustainable growth with price stability is the containment of inflation, the insurance that-
Order.
I think we will have to move on.

In fact, Mr. Speaker, the fundamentals are wrong. That is why we are facing the situation we are in this country.
I want to ask the minister about my own province of Ontario which has faced losses of $4.5 billion this year alone because of failed transfer payment commitments on the part of the federal government. I want to ask this minister if he is prepared to change his policies and see to it that the provinces of this country get a fair deal on transfer payments that they can count on so they do not have to face this kind of pressure right across this country.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member's province of Ontario will get something in the order of $10 billion in cash and tax transfer payments in this particular fiscal year. That represents an increase. The growth in transfer payments to the province of Ontario represents a higher rate of growth than Quebec, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, Newfoundland, British Columbia and Alberta.
The hon. member should know that. If he looks at the figures, he will find it very revealing to note that Ontario has not been short changed, nor have any of the other provinces been short changed. We have asked provinces to live within certain fiscal disciplines as we in the federal government have been.

April 30, 1992
Oral Questions CANADA POST

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister responsible for Canada Post. Earlier today the minister introduced measures to allow employees of Canada Post to buy shares in the Crown corporation.
Will the minister take this opportunity to admit to Canadians that he is embarking on the first steps of privatization of Canada Post?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not know why I would admit that. It would not be the truth if I were to do that as the hon. member will see from the bill. What the bill does is propose that there be stocks available for employees to participate in a savings plan, become a part of the company, feel a part of it, share in the growth in profits and profitability, productivity and so on.
The act makes it veiy clear that should in fact the decision be made about privatization of Canada Post, that would require separate legislation to come back to this House and there would be ample opportunity for people to make their choice between private ownership or state ownership if that comes up.
This minister has no intentions to bring forth that kind of legislation at this time.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, even Margaret Thatcher had enough sense not to privatize the British post office.

In his press release earlier today, the minister indicated that the investment plan would give employees a so-called share in the activities of Canada Post. Although some people may agree with the minister's reasoning-I for one do not-how can he claim to increase employee involvement when employees will be denied voting privileges on the shares they purchase?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker,the member should check his facts about Britain because part of the post office was indeed privatized. I
recognize that there are those who still believe that state ownership is superior to private ownership in all enterprises. I guess they will never learn and I am not going to attempt to change their minds.
On the question of the voting shares, employee stock owner savings plans, employee stock savings plans, which are used by about a quarter of the companies trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange, for example, do not require them to have voting privileges with them in order to accomplish their goals. In any event, voting would not make any sense because 90 per cent of the shares would still rest with the Crown. The Crown would still have total control.
What the hon. member is asking for does not really make sense. What this will provide is for employees of Canada Post to participate in the growth of this corporation as it continues to improve and continues to remain the most efficient, effective postal system in the world.

Mr. Speaker, business bankruptcies in Canada are up 11 per cent this month over last year. Maher Shoes is just one more casualty of this government's GST, cross-border shopping and other policies that favour U.S. retailers.
As of 2.30 p.m. today, seven minutes ago, neither the Minister of Employment and Immigration nor any of his officials had offered to help the 1,400 Maher employees who are being let out of work. I ask the Minister of Employment and Immigration why does he just not care?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, EIC officials are aware of the situation with respect to the Maher stores closure and will be meeting over the next few days with representatives of that company. EIC will extend its services through an industrial adjustment committee. We will ensure that all workers affected by this development have access to the full range of training and employment assistance programs.

The fact remains, Mr. Speaker, that as of right now there has been no contact with those employees.
April 30, 1992

This government has very seriously underestimated the levels of unemployment in Canada for this year. I ask the Minister of Employment and Immigration what new additional resources he has obtained to help retrain and relocate the thousands upon thousands of Canadians who are joining the ranks of Canada's unemployed.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
What we have obtained amounts to $400 million of more money that will be spent to train individual Canadians who become unemployed in this year.
Mr. Speaker, $3.4 billion is a large amount of money. It is essential that the responsibility to face those challenges of restructuring our economy be shared by all levels of government, even by the business and labour sector. That is what we are doing through the Labour Force Development Strategy, where for the first time in this country you have business and labour sitting together and looking at the training requirements of Canadians and advising the government, and hopefully impressing on the provinces the need to invest more into training Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the minister responsible for Canada Post.
In 1985 the Prime Minister said: "Air Canada is not for sale". The Deputy Prime Minister tried to infer in the House in 1988 that what he meant was that it was not for sale "at this time". Considering that the minister responsible for Canada Post has just used those words again, how can we trust the government not to try and privatize Canada Post in the near future?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will explain again that for any government to privatize Canada Post it would have to come forward to this Parliament with a bill where the hon. member and all members of Parliament could debate and vote on it.
Only when Parliament approves such a bill could Canada Post be privatized. Therefore, the hon. member should not be concerned about any sneak attack, some
Oral Questions
sneaky selling of shares to Canadians, because that is not possible without an act of Parliament. I do not have any plans at this time to bring forward legislation in that regard.
If the hon. member had come to the briefing I offered to members of the opposition earlier, I would have explained the rationale of the bill. I am sure he would have been comforted in terms of the direction we are going and what we are trying to accomplish.

Mr. Speaker, I can read the legislation. The minister knows that all it takes is a one line amendment in this legislation to open up the shares to anybody. They are establishing a share regime. The Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources is applauding. It indicates the purpose of this government. It is setting up a share regime to make privatization possible.
Why does this government not tell the truth to Canadians? Why not come clean? Why pretend? Why do another Air Canada run-around and lie to the people of Canada?
The hon. member has gone too far. I know he would want to withdraw that last comment, and I ask him to do so.
Mr. Speaker, very briefly, I withdraw the comment. The history speaks for itself.

That is not good enough. The hon. member feels very strongly about this matter and so probably do other hon. members, but we have to operate within the bounds of civility. I ask the hon. member, who is an experienced member, to make his withdrawal quite unequivocal, please.
Mr. Speaker, I do withdraw the remark. The government die not lie to the people. People can check the record and make their own interpretation.
Oh, oh.

I think I am going to have to ask the hon. member to perhaps just consider his position for a little while. I am going to come back and perhaps by then the hon. member will realize that an unequivocal withdrawal is just that and it is our tradition and it must be insisted on.
For the moment I am going on to the hon. member for Mississauga East.

April 30, 1992
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
Yesterday the minister admitted that he has a problem; 300,000 jobs, he says, were left unfilled last year because Canadian workers lacked the skills to apply. Why has the minister failed to admit that what has short changed these Canadian workers is this government's savage cutbacks in transfer payments for post-secondary education. When will the minister learn that his funding freeze has left many Canadians frozen out of the jobs that they so desperately need?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is incredible that someone can stand up in the House and tell Canadians when you look at the transfers to provinces that they have been cut. Even back home in Madawaska-Victoria, one plus one is still two. It does not seem to add up on that side of the House.
The member talks about the unemployed in her home province of Ontario. Yes, Canadians do lack training skills. In all of Canada we have tripled labour training money from $500 million in 1990 to $1.8 billion this year. If the argument is that we should do more, we agree we should do more, but we should do it with all the stakeholders in that economy.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday the minister repeatedly asked the Liberals to be part of the solution. I want to assure the minister that we will join with Canadians in creating that solution on election day.
The Prime Minister preaches that education and training are key to Canada's ability to compete internationally, yet his prophecy is not reflected in his budget papers.
I ask the minister to reconcile the Prime Minister's deeds with his fine words and restore funding to universities and colleges so that Canadians can qualify for the few jobs still available in the country.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if the hon. member looked at page 98, I believe, of the budget papers she would find that transfer payments to provinces have
grown very substantially. Transfer payments to provinces have grown from $25.6 billion in 1984-1985 to $38.9 billion this year. That certainly does not sound like a cut to me.
In her own province of Ontario during that period of time, the rate of growth of transfer payments has been more than 6 per cent annually. As I said earlier that growth rate is more than the growth rate in Quebec, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, Newfoundland and Labrador, British Columbia and Alberta. Ontario has been treated very generously.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister responsible for Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation.
The federal government has raided the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation's mortgage fund to the tune of $55 million. This government is robbing Peter to pay Paul when it takes the CMHC's mortgage insurance surplus to meet its own deficit targets.
Why is this government jeopardizing the integrity of the fund and potentially denying people the right to purchase their own home in the future?

speakeroldname: Hon. Elmer M. MacKay (Minister of Public Works):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation; Minister of Public Works
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my colleague knows that the mortgage insurance fund, thanks to good management by Canada Mortgage and Housing, can well afford to make this contribution to reducing the deficit, which is something that I think all members know is a very vital element to getting this economy growing again.
There is no connection between the payment to assist the Minister of Finance in this regard and the capability of Canada Mortgage and Housing to discharge its responsibilities.

Mr. Speaker, the minister should read his own briefing papers and documents. There was a pre-tax loss last year in the mortgage insurance fund of $27 million. CMHC's own economist forecasts an increase in the number of mortgage defaults this year, rising from $161 million in 1991 to $614 million in two years because of this government's economic policies.
April 30, 1992

In the face of continuing job losses, economic uncertainty and continuing recession, why is this government not protecting itself, homeowners, and future homeowners of this country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Elmer M. MacKay (Minister of Public Works):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation; Minister of Public Works
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I repeat to the House that careful actuarial calculations show that the mortgage insurance fund was well able to make this contribution to deficit reduction. I know my colleague will recognize that while there is no room for complacency in the housing sector there has been a noticeable improvement on the market side, even in social housing.
This government in difficult fiscal times has contributed $70 million more to the welfare of 1.5 million Canadians who are living in social housing.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Transport.
Last Sunday VIA Rail implemented a new schedule between Capreol and Hornpayne. That schedule effectively eliminated access to the properties of hundreds of people who live along that line. In fact the train is the only means of transportation into those properties.
I ask the minister if he will reverse VIA's unfair decision and allow these people unfettered access to their properties along that line.

Mr. Speaker, I guess that running a train operation is a little bit like politics.
Either you do like the socialists and not adapt to new circumstances and get wiped out completely after a number of years, or you adapt to normal circumstances to try to make the train more attractive to the people. People would use the train and you could keep it alive.
This is what VIA has done with its transcontinental. By making improvements to it, shortening the number of hours that people must travel on that route, they have done something that unfortunately does not serve all the cottagers who want to go to the train track, flag the train and the train will stop. This is no longer possible in modern days.
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, all I have to say is the minister has spoken like a politician whose party is peaking at 16 per cent.
We are not talking about politics. We are talking about access to property by permanent residents along that line, by people who have tourist businesses along that line and the train is their only means of transportation.
Is the minister prepared to instruct VIA to look at alternative methods of providing access to the properties by, for example, providing a bud car or speeding up the schedule between Toronto and Capreol, or by eliminating the 30 minutes idling in the Sudbury station and applying it to these stops?
We are talking about people and the access to their homes. We are not talking politics here for the minister's sake.

Mr. Speaker, in its new schedule adopted on April 26, VIA has cut the length of that train ride by two hours and forty-five minutes in order to attract people.
It has done a number of things. It has maintained the stops at all regular stations, even at the flagged stations, and is continuing to service the permanent residents of the area. However, it cannot adapt to the needs of all cottagers who want to get to the train track, wave the train down and have it stop. It cannot do that.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the President of the Treasury Board and concerns the misleading and disrespectful comments made by the minister when he said that the day after a vote for sovereignty, 70,000 Quebecers working for the federal government would be out of a job. I want to ask the minister to apologize and say, as he has done in the past, that he will respect his government's commitment to recognizing Quebec's right to self-determination and above all, that he promises to stop making these threats which are merely-

One moment, please. I am sorry, but I think we may have a problem here. I believe the hon. member said the minister spoke in a way that was "misleading". If that is the case, I would of course ask the hon. member to make the appropriate statement, because this term is not acceptable.

April 30, 1992
Oral Questions
I apologize, Mr. Speaker, and I withdraw the word "misleading", but I maintain that the minister was irresponsible in referring the way he did to government employees-
The hon. member will agree that he is getting into debate. However, I want to thank him for withdrawing the word he used. The minister has the floor.

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as a former journalist I would never dream of saying I was misquoted. However, although I may have disappointed the hon. member I would like to mention something else I said as well which may have escaped him. I was asked the following question: Do you think sovereignty for Quebec would mean jobs would be lost? My answer was: I do not think we have reached that stage yet. In fact, I am very confident, in view of the events of the past few months, that we will be able to solve this problem and will not have to go through that kind of crisis. However, if people suggest other solutions, we will have to understand exactly what they mean and draw our own conclusions.
I would say that I made an assumption that is not altogether unrealistic. The federal government provides services to ten provinces and two territories. The Government of Canada also has a capital, whose activities cover both Ottawa and Hull, I would say. I think the hon. member would agree that if Quebec withdraws, it will not ask us to provide government services in Quebec. So federal public servants will be removed. The capital of Canada would not be in a foreign country but in Canada, and people would move.
In any case, I merely said what was said by his leader, Mr. Parizeau, who has been visiting the Gatineau-Hull region every month to tell people: Don't worry, we will pick you up. They would first have to be dropped.

Mr. Speaker, the minister knows perfectly well that at the present time, Quebec is contributing its fair share which is 25 per cent to support the federal Public Service. In Quebec we now have 17 per cent of the federal Public Service. The
minister knows perfectly well that once federal public servants in Quebec have been absorbed, we will also save $1.2 billion.
I want to ask the minister whether, as soon as Quebec becomes independent, the government will make arrangements for a civilized transfer of these employees?

speakeroldname: Hon. Gilles Loiselle (President of the Treasury Board and Minister of State (Finance)):
speakerposition: President of the Treasury Board; Minister of State (Finance)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my answer is simply that this government does not intend to fire any Quebecers from the Public Service.
If there is a problem it will be the hon. member's fault.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance. The latest Conservative budget cut $622 million from social housing. According to Gilles Fournier of the Point St. Charles welfare recipients' committee, this irresponsible policy abandons 574,000 low income Quebec households. Is the Minister of Finance prepared to immediately restore the funds for social housing and to stop punishing the least fortunate in our society?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the social housing increases will amount to $70 million this year over the previous year.
I should also remind the hon. member that the people of Canada spend $2 billion on social housing and notwithstanding that fact there was still a provision for an additional $70 million. Two billion dollars is a lot of money.
I think it has been a good program. It has had to be constrained because of the growth, it has had to be constrained consistent with our inflationary levels. What we are proposing is a growth at the rate of 3 per cent per year.

The hon. member has the floor for a short supplementary question.
April 30, 1992

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in Montreal alone, these budget cuts mean that 500 new units will not be built this year, although 10,000 people are on the waiting list for social housing.
How can the minister justify completely abandoning these residents of the Montreal area, where more than 615,000 people live in poverty?

speakeroldname: Hon. Elmer M. MacKay (Minister of Public Works):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation; Minister of Public Works
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, my colleague should know there are other programs besides the co-op which are well able to cope with people who have core need. I also want to remind him that while this is not a complete answer there is a surplus of social housing in certain areas of Montreal.
I will take a single question from the hon. member for LaSalle-Emard and a single question from the hon. member for New Westminster-Burnaby.

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Port Moody was the original terminus of what used to be a great railway, the Transcontinental Railway. The terminus then moved into Vancouver, but Port Moody is a thriving municipality in the suburbs of Vancouver.
Having said that, I will return to my speech which I am sure the House is awaiting with bated breath to hear. Before lunch I was speaking on this bill which proposes to cut back a number of commissions and government bodies. I had said that I was not against cutbacks per se, and I know the government was surprised about that. I
April 30, 1992

Government Orders
am not against cutbacks. If we can save the taxpayers' money then fine and good, but the point was that some of these cutbacks were very ideological in nature, were not going to save the government much money at all, and might even cost the government more money than it would save.
Let us take the Law Reform Commission as an example. It is going to be cut back. The government is going to lose all the advice of this commission. It is going to lose some of the studies, independent advice, and so on. I was just saying before lunch that we were working on a bill in committee today called the Contraventions Act which came out of a law reform report in 1976. The government was getting value for its money.
Instead the government is cutting things like the Law Reform Commission and the Court Challenges Program. That amounts to about $6 million for the two of them, and it is giving an extra $16 million to some fat lawyers, specifically government law firms, its friends in Vancouver, Montreal and Toronto. I say that is no way to save money at all.
I am going to focus more specifically on the Law Reform Commission. The decision to get rid of the commission was a sudden one. It took everyone by surprise. The president of the commission, Mr. Gilles Letoumeau, a distinguished academic and lawyer, got the news one hour before the budget speech. Now there is planning for you; there is Tory planning.
The president of the Federation of Law Reform Agencies of Canada, Mr. Arthur Close, upon hearing of the dismantling of the Commission said:
Systematic and continuous law reform is not a luxury. It is a
necessity in a society that is governed by legislation and the common
law.
He is saying that they did not cut back a luxury; they cut back a necessity.
The government has said that the decision to include the Law Reform Commission in its cuts was based upon the sad fact that Canadians could no longer afford what it believes is a luxury, what the Minister of Justice has called a Cadillac approach to research. I do not know how she would know what a Cadillac was. She spends most of her time running around in some rich government car, but she called it a Cadillac approach to law research.
I believe that may not be an accurate representation of the facts. Cutting the Law Reform Commission is not fiscally responsible government. It is merely another manifestation of the mean spirited and vindictive philosophy that dictates this government's decisions. It is symptomatic of a siege mentality that rewards those who support it and attacks those who do not.
For example, before Christmas the Law Reform Commission came up with a report suggesting that there should be a separate native justice system. The minister is against that. Bang, there goes the Law Reform Commission. Notice the pattern it follows.
The Economic Council of Canada brought forward some news with respect to Quebec and the price of separatism. That was not the line the government was peddling at the moment. Suddenly, the Economic Council of Canada is expendable. Am I being paranoid here? Am I seeing conspiracies? Perhaps. It is interesting that when there is a report against the government by an independent commission, bang, that commission is gone.
The minister said that the Law Reform Commission was a Cadillac. If it is a Cadillac we have had some very good mileage out of it. It is a very good investment. In fact, we have bought a Cadillac at mid-size prices. A tradition has been established in the legal community of giving time and resources to the Law Reform Commission. I am certain that tradition of giving those resources will not extend to the Department of Justice, which will have to do the research that the Law Reform Commission did. Who is going to save money? In the long run we are going to have more bureaucrats and it is going to cost more money rather than saving money.
The president of the Canadian Bar Association, J.J. Camp, when asked about the demise of the Law Reform Commission, said: "The cost of outdated laws which hinder all Canadians in their daily business is immeasurably higher". In other words, having a bunch of outdated laws costs more money than it costs to allow the Law Reform Commission to make reports to change those laws.
A perfect example is the Contraventions Act, the bill which we are debating before this very Parliament, which was originally proposed by the Law Reform Commission. The minister herself will acknowledge that.

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
The recommendation of the Law Reform Commission in 1975 that Crown attorneys fully disclose their case to the defence counsel has led to a change in practice that has served both federal and provincial governments, as well as private citizens, and saved millions of dollars every year.
Ironically, just one day after the announcement that the Law Reform Commission was to be dismantled a ruling from the Supreme Court of Canada in the case of Clunes against the Queen that upheld the joinder of charges cited extensively from the Law Reform Commission's working paper on the charged document entitled: The Charged Document in Criminal Cases.
The Supreme Court of Canada came down with a decision citing the Law Reform Commission, thanking the Law Reform Commission and using the Law Reform Commission. The day after the government gets rid of the Law Reform Commission.
That ruling will hopefully lead to a more efficient use of the courts. I hope the government will take notice. We in the NDP would like to see the courts opened to everyone. We would like to see an efficient court system. We would like to see access to justice for the ordinary citizen. We think that the Law Reform Commission's work in that area was worth the bucks.
The government wants to save money. It costs $800,000 a year for the Prime Minister to get his morning's press clippings. We could save that money. It cost something like $54,000 a day for the Prime Minister and his entourage to visit Paris. How about cutting some of that money?
Those of us who have had the pleasure of sitting on the committee that reviewed amendments to the insanity laws know what it is like to have to work on legislation that is under a deadline set by the Supreme Court of Canada. It results in hurried law making.
This kind of process is a shame when one recalls that the Law Reform Commission called for reform of the insanity laws going back to 1976. First, the Liberal government and then the Conservative government did not act on it. Then we had to wait for the Supreme Court of Canada to rule that the insanity laws were unconstitutional and we had to hurriedly change them through Parliament. We did that with some co-operation from all parties but it was difficult. We could have operated in a better mode, found a better way of doing things.
The Minister of Justice gave a speech on April 14 honouring the 10th anniversary of the charter. She made note of a disturbing trend among legislators, that they tend to leave difficult decisions to the courts. That was the whole point of her speech. She said, if I can paraphrase it, that we celebrate the Charter of Rights and Freedoms but she was disturbed that Canadians were looking to the courts for everything. They should be looking to Parliament.
She made note, and I agree with this somewhat, of this trend among legislators of leaving difficult decisions to the courts. She said: "There is a great temptation to avoid dealing with contentious issues by saying let us wait until the courts tell us what we have to do". She is right in identifying our abdication of responsibilities as parliamentarians.
Canadians have sent us to the House of Commons to change existing antiquated and unfair laws and write new laws to establish guidelines as to how this country is governed, according to the wishes of the people. That is the democratic process. I am pleased to say that the minister has made this public commitment.
However, the minister should pay heed to her own words about the democratic process being a process of balancing interests and seeking compromises through public consultation. She said: "The essence of law making is the balance of interests. By reasons of their unique institutional characteristics, legislatures are in the best position to assess competing demands and strike the appropriate balances. Legislatures are broadly representative bodies. With their research and consultative mechanisms they have the capacity to gather and assess the socio-economic data upon which public policy-making is based".
Exactly. That is what the Law Reform Commission did. It could get that data for the government.
What are we going to do? Now we are going to do it in house. It is not going to be opened up and we are going to have a worse system.
On the one hand the minister can laud the resources available to Parliament and on the other hand cut off those very resources. You cannot say that we celebrate the charter and access to justice and then on the other hand cut off the Court Challenges Program thereby stopping people from having that access.
April 30, 1992

The Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship is in the House. I hope he can find a way, as he has often done in the past in the intricacies of the budget of this department, to find some way to keep some of this independent research and some of the energy of the Court Challenges Program people going. I hope he can do that.
I wonder how much of the $4.8 million that the government said it will save through this cut will actually be realized. The minister said that much of the work will be done on contract through the Department of Justice. It seems to me that this is a fraud and that we are not really saving the $4 million. In fact, we are going to spend that money through private contracts and so on. Why destroy something that is working? Why destroy another good element of Canadian society that is working?
Other countries have law reform commissions. There are only two in the Commonwealth now that do not have them.
I am going to conclude and allow members to ask me questions. My speech is pretty straightforward. I am not against cuts but let us look at what they are and let us not destroy something that is working. Let us not destroy something that is helping this Parliament for a regime that will cost the taxpayers more and be less effective.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I must say I was delighted to hear my hon. friend concluding his remarks by saying that he is not against cuts. I noticed that he and his colleagues are not against cuts, except for the ones we make when we have to deal with budgetary realities in this country.
I want to speak specifically to the issue of the Law Reform Commission, which he spoke very eloquently on behalf of. I expect that when he was in practice his clients were very well served by him.
I must tell the member that I did indeed receive a letter from the Nova Scotia Bar Association expressing its concern about this decision. It is important and the Minister of Justice and the Minister of Finance have said that they respect and recognize the very excellent work
Government Orders
that has been done over the years by the Law Reform Commission. That is not really what is at issue here, not why this decision has been made.
It needs to be commended for the work it has done. The question is whether that is the only way the work can be done. The question is what the expectations of Canadians are with respect to the finances of their government.
Canadians have told this government that they want government that is leaner and meaner, they want us to very carefully guard their tax dollars. Times have changed since the Law Reform Commission was established. Since that time the capacity of law schools to do research has increased incredibly. The Canadian Bar Association itself is doing much more work and excellent work. Le Barreau du Quebec is doing good work, and work is being done by federal and provincial governments.
It is not as if the kind of work that has been done by the Law Reform Commission of Canada will cease if the Law Reform Commission ceases to exist. It is very important that kind of research continues to take place.
I remind my hon. friend of some very important legal reforms that have taken place during this Parliament, for example firearms control, the sexual assault issue, extradition, and mental disorders. These are issues that have been brought forward by members of Parliament in this Chamber and because of the work of people here.
Law reform is possible in Canada even without the Law Reform Commission.
We must put this in context. If the government is faced with doing what the Canadian people want, in terms of downsizing government and rationalizing institutions, and if we are prepared to recognize that times change and therefore structures must change in response to the times then this is an appropriate decision.
I would invite my hon. friend to reflect upon these observations. I look forward to hearing him renew his support for fiscal restraint and cutting when cutting is necessary, as we feel it was in this case.

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank the member for his question and for his compliments at the beginning of his question and statement.

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
Yes, I have to agree that law reform is possible without a Law Reform Commission. However, the advantage of the Law Reform Commission was that there was a structure in place that was working.
I thought the essence of conservatism was to not destroy things that were working in the interest of uncharted radicalism, so I wonder why a Conservative government would destroy something that was working. Not only was it working but it was independent. That is very important because the Law Reform Commission was an advisory body to Parliament, not just to the government.
Of course law reform will be done, partially in house by the Department of Justice. I mean no disrespect toward the civil service and the Department of Justice but they are busy with a lot of things, mainly day-to-day things, and have trouble looking down the road a year, never mind five years.
Also there are outside agencies. Will the government commit itself to give contracts for law research to law schools and other groups?
The Lmw Reform Commission was doing that so that is nothing new. The problem is that the Law Reform Commission studies were all public. They were all open. This government is showing an increased penchant for being secret, you have to drag information out of them by using the Freedom of Information Act. Even then the responses have been restricted.
The answer to the hon. member's question is that we need the Law Reform Commission. There are other ways of saving money. There are lots of other ways of saving money. We are going to end up with a system that is worse than we are getting because we had an open system that had real effects.
The member mentioned gun control and so on. The Law Reform Commission was active on all these issues decades ago. It did work on the insanity laws and the extradition laws. It did work on native justice, which we are now debating in the new constitutional proposals.
Of course, they did work on bills, such as the bills we have before this Parliament on the effect of federal laws for minor criminal matters called the Contraventions Act.
If it is working, why fix it? The reason is that these are ideological cuts, or just to pull the wool over the
taxpayers' eyes and pretend that this is a frugal government that is saving the taxpayer a lot of money when in fact it is quite spendthrift and has wasted a lot of money.

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise today to make a few remarks on Bill C-63.
I will confine my remarks to the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council. This council was set up in 1977 and was designed to respond to a set of needs in a public environment that is quite unlike today's public environment.
1980 was the decade during which the Canadian public had only begun to seize opportunities for a say in government decision making.
The technological and educational advances that grew out of the Second World War had, by the 1980s, produced a more aware, more demanding public that wanted to be a part of policy making. Concrete, practical public input could produce solid, workable policies.
In many cases, there was no vehicle through which to provide that input. To respond to that need, the advisory council was established after much discussion among Employment and Immigration Canada, employers and union groups.
This was a deliberate move to provide public input into policy development at a time when the public environment in Canada was only beginning to open up to such input. The membership of the advisory council was split into three, one-third from business, one-third from labour and one-third from other interested groups.
At the time this made sense. Since then, however, the whole area of public consultation has grown tremendously. Looking at it now, I think we need a different kind of representation, one that varies according to subject matter.
For example, today there are a number of groups such as immigrant service organizations, community college representatives and ethnic groups which must be included if one is studying such a subject as immigrant language training.
April 30, 1992

Over the last decade, Employment and Immigration Canada has responded to these changes. In terms of the immigration program, which was a very structured and narrow consultation on proposed immigration levels each year, has grown into a much more flexible, multifaceted, ongoing consultation on many more aspects of the whole immigration program.
Employers and union groups are still consulted because of the important link between the labour market and immigration. As well, relatively new but major players in immigration issues must and should now be included. This process is a reflection of what Canadians want, direct focus on an input into important government programs.
Looking at the employment program side of Employment and Immigration Canada, the same impetus from the public was at work and essentially produced, after much study and discussion among labour market partners, the Canadian Labour Force Development Board.
The board is now in the process of setting up provincial and local boards, thus pushing consultation and decision making further down into the community on the grounds that the closer one is to the labour market, the better the decision making.
The make-up of the new board at the national, provincial and local level is again employers, union representatives, educators, trainers and specific social action groups represented by the Canadian labour force.
Federal government training and employment programs cover an awful lot of ground, and they affect thousands of Canadians. The users of these programs will have the opportunity to play a larger role in the design and delivery of these programs.
Another important area of growth and change in the 1980s was aboriginal training. Through the new National Aboriginal Management Board, Employment and Immigration Canada is once again putting decision making and priority setting into the hands of users. This board will provide a bottom-up type of decision making with a special focus on aboriginal employment issues. Here
Government Orders
again this is a development that came out of the massive changes of the 1970s and 1980s in Canada.
I know that the cynics say that we are closing the council because we are not interested in having public input at Employment and Immigration Canada. The fact is the council has really outlived its usefulness in the face of increased demands for more and wider consultation.
I speak from a little bit of experience as I had a constituent, Bronwyn Shoush, who served on this board. She served on the board for 18 months. In fact, the last few months all three component groups had not replaced their membership. They were running out of steam. The government had been consulting widely with other groups, the Labour Force Development Board on the employment side, immigration groups, ethnic groups and other groups on the immigration side. She indicated to me that this board was redundant. It was spinning its wheels a little bit and she has no regrets that the board is being wound down.
Some members opposite may be familiar with some of the good work that the council has produced over the years. It has been very good work. In 1985 and again in 1986 the council reported on the situation of older workers in Canada. This is a very huge problem in Canada. These reports contributed to the development of the program for older worker adjustment. This program has been a good step at helping older workers adjust, older workers retrain, and we could do more in this area.
In 1987 the council studied the issue of workers with family responsibilities and, there again, put forward some very valuable ideas. As an advisory body to the minister, the council has studied issues it was asked by ministers to look at and it has used its own initiative to examine questions its own members have thought important. In any event, these reports were very welcome.
Since the advisory council was not established as either a decision making or an advocacy body, but as strictly advisory in the policy making process, it fulfilled the role it was designed for. Now it is time to recognize that that role is at an end, that other groups and mechanism have evolved.

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
I spoke earlier about the breadth and depth of the consultation we need at Employment and Immigration Canada. Let us face it, as far as the Canadian labour market goes, things have completely changed since the 1970s. The ability and willingness of labour market partners to participate in the policy making process has grown as the general public's demand for more say in decisions. A small organization, such as the advisory council, simply cannot respond to the many complex issues coming to us in the 1990s. It was never designed to do so.
We should also recognize the bridging role that the advisory council served when it was set up in 1977. The Department of Manpower and Immigration at the time and the Unemployment Insurance Commission had been amalgamated in the late 1970s. There was a lot of uncertainty about the implications of that move. Fifteen years later, this is no longer the case.
Today we know that it will take more and better consultations to get Canada through the massive adjustment and education process necessary for a continued and future prosperity, consultations on a scale which surpasses the council's role and so the closing of the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council is a necessary step. The council should and has been acknowledged for the task it has accomplished. We must also acknowledge that the advisory council has been overtaken by events in a fast moving, changeable world.
On one side we have the Labour Force Development Board; on the other side we have widespread and ongoing consultation on the immigration side. These are very appropriate today. I will finish with those remarks.

Mr. Speaker, that is a good question. Let me answer it by indicating to the hon. member that what was created were labour force development boards at a local level.
We did not want a 22-member council, elite in nature, which was unable to respond to local labour market needs. Therefore, we created local labour force and provincial labour force boards all across the country to respond to local employment needs. This is much better than a 22-person council at a national level trying to respond to both local and national needs.
We are saving $22 million a year. That is over $100 million in five years. It is a necessary move. In its place we have Canadian labour market boards which are much more responsive. Canadians want government to respond to their needs. We are always talking about greater autonomy and greater responsiveness and greater service of government organizations, and this is precisely what these new boards are doing.
This agency became redundant. It was an elite organization of 22 people from three sectors of society. We need to broaden our consultations. The labour development boards have members from varied backgrounds all across the spectrum of society. These people and these boards are able to respond in a very efficient and positive way to local labour market needs.
