speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank you for this opportunity to participate in the debate on this bill which dissolves the International Centre for Ocean Development, as well as four other public corporations.
April 30, 1992

I must admit that, like all those concerned, I have mixed feelings regarding the difficult decision made by the government to eliminate a total of 46 corporations of similar status. This decision was announced in the last budget. I am well aware of the fact that these agencies worked in a vast number of fields and that they were useful.
I have a lot of respect for the efforts made by the staff of these corporations and I regret that, following this decision, their careers are disrupted. I sincerely hope that this career change will prove beneficial, in the long run, for each and every one of those people.
That being said, I must also state that I support the decision made by the government. I am convinced that in the long run, this decision will serve the interests of the Canadian population.
I want to talk in particular about the International Centre for Ocean Development, the ICOD, whose head office is in Halifax. This centre was created in 1985 to help small sovereign island states benefit from the new economic zones extending off their shores. Those benefits were the results of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea.
In the last seven years, the ICOD has implemented a diversified program which includes scholarships, training programs and other initiatives in the field of training and information. The centre has gathered Canadian expertise in the field of ocean development and has contributed to the establishment of links between businesses and consultants in Canada and in some developing countries which can take advantage of their abilities and skills.
This is all very good. A corporation was set up and it fulfilled its mandate. Why then did the government proceed, seven years later, to dissolve the ICOD? The answer is a painful one, but it is based on hard facts.
The government took this action because times have changed, because decisions are not eternal and because public corporations are not immortal.
The government made this decision because we have to live according to our means, because we live in an increasingly competitive world where the slogan "to
Government Orders
make more with less" is no longer just a slogan but a condition of survival.
The government realized, rightly so, that it is vital to streamline and modernize our public sector. Why? Because it entails fixed costs, overhead costs which, traditionally, have been high in Canada, since our Public Service is rather large, given the population of our country. In a way, this situation is unavoidable and totally justified, given the geography and social realities of our country.
It is precisely because of those factors that the government must make cuts wherever possible, so that we remain able to finance our most vital services, social programs and institutions. This is what we must do if we want our country to be in the best possible conditions to face the stiff competition that awaits us.
I agree that it would be highly desirable to have a top-flight national institution, a public corporation that would look after each and every aspect of all the great problems and challenges that confront us. There is no doubt in my mind that these agencies would do a good job. However, this is simply not a realistic scenario. It is a luxury that we cannot afford.
In a way, the decision made by the government is similar to the one that an individual must make before buying a car. It would be nice to choose the top-of-the-line model and to tell the salesperson: "With every possible option, please". Well, the government has shown enough determination to say: "Only the basic model". I salute that firmness.
In the case of the ICOD, which is a very specialized agency, it must be noted that its programs and commitments will be integrated to the work being done by the Canadian International Development Agency, CIDA. For numerous years, CIDA has been providing assistance to developing countries in fields such as fisheries and ocean management.
In fact, there is still another agency for co-operation supported with public monies and whose mandate includes marine resources. I am referring to the International Development Research Centre. There are also groups of experts in various Canadian universities, for instance Dalhousie University, Memorial University, YUniversite du Quebec in Rimouski, and the University of

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
British Columbia. There are top-calibre businesses in our country, some of which will benefit from the expertise of former employees of the ICOD. On the international scene, there are various organizations and programs to help developing countries to better benefit from their fisheries and marine resources.
I therefore think that Canada will have many opportunities to help these countries manage their marine resources well and protect this crucial part of our environment.
I hope that the United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development will lead to wise initiatives in this area, but I do not believe that all this depends on maintaining ICOD.
The various objectives that I mentioned can perhaps be achieved more efficiently in the long run in other ways. If we can act and achieve our objectives so as to reduce costs and channel funds from the aid budget to the programs themselves instead of spending them on administration, if we can do that, I approve of the government's decision.
In the years to come, Canada will take part in international activities on many important problems. In theory, we could tackle each of these problems and show that we take a certain issue seriously by establishing a specialized agency to implement any major agreement on a particular question. But in the end such an approach would be doomed to failure.
We have only limited resources. We do not need to set up a top-heavy superstructure of public agencies and specialized institutions. On the other hand, we must be able to count on a slimmed-down, efficient and flexible Public Service that can deal with the whole range of issues that interest Canada; a Public Service that can use taxpayers' money as efficiently and effectively as possible.
I have the feeling that the government is moving resolutely in that direction. I believe that the decision announced in the budget to end many organizations and boards, although it will certainly be criticized and protested in various quarters, was appropriate.
We must cut our spending. We must make cuts in all fields and it is possible to do so. We must lighten our
burden. Such action is essential and in the national interest.
We in Canada have a problem that is casting a shadow on the future of our children and of our country. This problem, quite simply, is the public debt. By taking consistent, determined action, this government has managed to gain considerable control of the situation, despite all expectations. We are now at the point where revenue and expenditure balance, if the cost of servicing the accumulated debt is not counted. In fact, this cost corresponds to the federal budget deficit that we still incur every year.
As far as I am concerned, of course I support this action. Regardless of the things that ICOD and the other agencies have going for them, the government must make balancing the budget and restoring our country's economic health the top priority.
I support the government's effort to overcome our basic financial problem and I call on all hon. members to do the same.

subtopic: CANADA EMPLOYMENT AND IMMIGRATION ADVISORY COUNCIL
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, earlier this week, I believe on Monday, we talked about a motion asking the government to call an election because of the terrible economic conditions. I know that a lot of members on the government side thought we were being political and cynical.
However, after listening to government members today and the way in which they talked about institutions that have served this country so well for so long I know that we were on the right track on Monday.
We talk about the fact that our interest rates are the lowest they have been in over 20 years. There is absolutely no inflation in this country today, nothing to speak of. It is probably under 2 per cent. Yet we have a crisis of confidence in this country. People are not spending. Those people with a job seem to be more nervous than those without a job. When you see a bill like this, Bill C-63, an act to dissolve or terminate certain corporations or other bodies, it is just the language of it, to dissolve or terminate institutions like the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council of Canada, the Law Reform Commission, the International Centre for Ocean Development, and the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council.
April 30, 1992

When I listened to the President of the Treasury Board today, and he is a member that I have a high level of respect for, I took notes when he spoke. He said there is a five point reason why we are dissolving these agencies. He talked about waste, duplication, consolidating and privatization. I forget what the fifth one was.
The point is the government has forgotten what the whole purpose was behind these institutions. Many years ago in Ottawa the opposition never really had a chance at properly debating the government because the government basically controlled all of the resources. The purpose of giving money for research to opposition parties, for setting up instruments like the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada was to make sure the quality of debate, the level of debate, in this Chamber ultimately served the people of Canada. The purpose was to make sure the independence of thinking was assured so the departmental advice that ministers were receiving could have a third party check. They had to be quality organizations.
In many ways these agencies were not unlike our Auditor General. Our Auditor General basically has the ability to go into any department at will, any time, analyse, audit and report to Parliament as to the effectiveness of the management skills, the use of the taxpayers money. I do not think anyone in this House would dare think of saying let us abolish the Auditor General.
I think the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada are not unlike the function of the Auditor General of Canada. These institutions, and I am only going to focus on those two today, are think-tanks of the highest order. They attract the best and brightest minds in this country. Because they are organizations that have respect, they have access in turn to some of the best and brightest minds all over the world.
They have built networks that have served government after government. It did not matter whether it was a Liberal government or a Conservative government. These independent agencies never really cared who was in power. I know when the Liberal government was here from 1980 to 1984, the Economic Council of Canada repeatedly gave information to the government or gave
Government Orders
advice to the government, or even criticized the government at times when it was not on the right track. That, to me, is really a healthy thing in this Government of Canada operation. If all of a sudden you get in the habit of basically dismantling anything that gives you resistance, where do you stop? Where will this lead to? When times are tough and you need that quality talent, you need minds focused on how we get our economy going; where will you turn, where will you go? These think-tanks are just not sitting on every street comer. You just cannot call the local university and say: "Listen, prepare a study for me on how we can put people back to work in this country". It was a tremendous investment of time and money to attract the best and brightest minds in this country to develop the reputation and the quality of work that the Economic Council of Canada has acquired.
I think that the government in this case is really not choosing the right priorities. When you have a crisis of confidence like we have in this country, and it is incumbent on all of us to work on rebuilding that confidence, you do not turn to organizations like the Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada with their reputations and just say: "We are going to terminate you". If anything, quite frankly their budgets should probably be increased during a tough time like this.
The minister responsible for the Treasury Board said $22 million. That is to operate all six of these organizations. Yet we can bum $15 million on an advertising campaign that talks about "We can do it". I suppose the government is doing this campaign because it recognizes that there is a problem with confidence in the country. I share that concern. But if the government could find $15 million to talk about an advertising campaign that probably will not last for more than about 8, 10 or 12 weeks, could we not somewhere in the system find the money to keep independent think-tanks like the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada going?
I think the government has really missed on this one. It is this kind of action that can exacerbate the lack of confidence in the market. With the low inflation rate and the low interest rate, the government does have a little bit of room. The government should recognize that these

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
institutions have served us well and it should rethink it and probably pull this bill.
The other document that the government is talking about a lot these days is Living Well; Learning Well. How can you spend all that money on Living Well; Learning Well, expect to have credibility, and at the same time terminate these other organizations? It just does not wash in my mind.
The creative process is the most powerful process of all. What this government is saying by terminating these organizations is putting that creative process into a second class in the face of deficit reduction.
That is why we are doing it. Think of what the contracting out costs will be when as the months roll by we will no doubt need the service of some of these institutions. We are going to be calling the Department of Supply and Services to request similar services.
There is not a member on the government side who can say that we are going to end up getting the quality and the amount of service that these organizations have been providing for less money. When we get to contracting out, we are probably going to end up paying a lot more money.
What kind of signal does it send to the rest of the people in this country who are involved in research? There was a time-that time was probably just up until a couple of months ago-that there were people all across the country, many of them, who aspired to do work for the Economic Council of Canada.
Now all of a sudden, we throw it out. It is not right. It is this kind of dismantling operation, this kind of retreat from governments that exacerbates the problem that we have with the confidence factor in this country. If we were to maybe take some of these organizations and tell them that we want to see more life or if we want to see a greater service, give them the direction. Give them the leadership. Do not just say "Good-bye, you are gone".
Believe me, this kind of action by the government will affect the entire Public Service. It shows an attitude and a lack of appreciation toward quality service that has been around here for a long, long time. It is not the kind of action that, quite frankly, breeds loyalty. Right now we need loyalty in this country. We need loyalty and we
need a condition where people will rally together. This bill works against that.
I go back to a comment that a member from New Brunswick made earlier today: "Canada is not a balance sheet". This was a member on the government side. He said: "Canada is not a balance sheet". I agree with him. Canada is not a balance sheet.
We are here, of course, in this Chamber to make sure that the taxpayers' money which we have been entrusted with is spent wisely. We are not like a business in the sense that we are looking for a profit at the end of every month. We are in the business of making sure that people function to their maximum potential.
Organizations like the Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada are organizations that have a creative force that stimulates each and every member in this House and all kinds of people in the business community. That stimulation leads to the creation of jobs. It leads to the creation of new opportunities. It leads to the collective creative process in this country working to its maximum potential.
As the member from New Brunswick said earlier today: "Canada is not a balance sheet". He was so right right when he made that statement. We are in this place to try and mobilize and to galvanize the national will. We need instruments, we need think-tanks and we need the people who work in those institutions like the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada. We need those people working with all of their energy. I think to come along and terminate them is the wrong way to go.

Bill C-63 issues death warrants on the following commissions and agencies. It has issued death warrants on the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council of Canada, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the International Centre for Ocean Development, the Law Reform Commission and, of course, the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council and the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security.
We heard earlier in the debate that some of these agencies can be contracted out to private enterprise. The Liberal Party is not against privatization, but there has to be a bit of sense about what you privatize and what you do not privatize. What you do not privatize is input from Canadians. You do not give that to a lobby group that is going to raise the most money for a certain party.
I would like to share my recent experience in Washington just three weeks ago, when members from both sides of this House attended an international conference on Cyprus. We heard from many congressmen and senators. The congressmen and senators who spoke to us were lobbied very hard by Greek Cypriots living in the United States of America. They made excellent presentations. You could see that the fundraising was done for these congressmen by this lobby group in Washington and, therefore, they were giving a certain point of view on how to solve the Cyprus situation.
One lobbyist raised $6 million for President Bush's campaign. All he had to do was write a letter to President Bush and President Bush responds that he will personally look into the Cyprus problem.
Now, that is the direction this government is taking this country if we are not careful. Those are not the kinds of points of view that I want to see brought to any government in Canada or to any member. The kinds of councils and commissions that are on the chopping block give not only a point of view of Canadians, they give a field of view. That is the difference.
As we know, the Minister of Finance in presenting his budget on February 25, announced his intention to "eliminate, consolidate, defer or privatize 46 Crown
The lobbyists give to the government a point of view. Many of these 46 agencies, but especially these 6, give the government a field of view. That is healthy.

April 30, 1992

The government is trying to silence these organizations because they have been presenting a field of view that has not been the kind of message that the government wanted to receive. Therefore, it is going to silence them by abolishing them. That is a very scary direction in which this government is taking this country. I hope Canadians are listening.
Earlier today I heard the term rationalize said many times by members opposite, rationalize to terminate the jobs of at least 300 Canadians working for the Economic and Science Councils, the Law Reform Commission, the Canadian Institute for Peace and Security and many more valuable institutions. Rationalize, I find it difficult to see any rationale behind these cuts.
I looked up the definition of rationalize in the Oxford Dictionary. The dictionary states: "Rationalize: to make industry more scientifically efficient". That is what these agencies and organizations have been doing.
The Economic Council of Canada, the agency which provides objective, non-partisan advice to government on how to make Canada's workers more competitive and more efficient in the global economy, is being slashed in the name of saving money. The government is spending millions talking to Canadians about how Canadians should be more competitive and more productive and yet it is getting rid of the very council giving advice on how Canadians can be more productive and more competitive. This is not rational. It is not scientific.
The Science Council of Canada, the agency which recommended the creation of the Canadian Space Agency, which encouraged Canadian scientists such as Dr. Roberta Bondar to participate in valuable research, which urged Canadians to start recycling is being slashed in the name of saving money. This simply does not make economic sense.
None of the arguments we have heard from the government side of the House today are either rational or scientific. I suspect that the government is either penny wise or pound foolish. More likely this government, as I mentioned in the House yesterday, is just bankrupt of ideas.
For example, the Canadian fishing industry is in crisis and the government is closing down the International Centre for Ocean Development, the ICOD. How does the government expect the rest of the international community to help save our Atlantic cod stocks when we renege on our promise to be a world leader in ocean development, to foresee problems in advance and create
Government Orders
a sustainable food supply? Ask any Atlantic fishermen what he thinks about the government today and he or she will tell you what they think about rationalization.
What about the Law Reform Commission, which is also on the chopping block? The elimination of the Law Reform Commission will mean that Canada will be one of only three Commonwealth countries without an independent law reform body. The other two are Bangladesh and Zimbabwe.
In some areas of my riding of Parkdale-High Park there are people afraid to walk the streets. I am not speaking here about Los Angeles or New York, I am talking about Parkdale-High Park in Canada. Canadians expect to be protected from crime, to be protected from the drug dealers, the pimps and the muggers. Canadians expect a legal system which protects them.
Why then is the Law Reform Commission being shut down? My constituents want to know.
Bill C-63 is legislation that does not make sense. I urge my colleagues from all three parties to think twice before supporting it. I hope that we will get members from all three parties opposing Bill C-63.
Look at the volatility in the world around us. Look at the new democracies which have sprung up around the world. We all welcomed the new democracies in Eastern Europe but the government seeks to eliminate the Canadian International Institute for Peace and Security. This is an agency which provides advice to our own government on such things as how Canada can be of assistance to these infant democracies in their development toward free market economies, which is what we would like to see.
As associate critic for external affairs I would like to spend a little more time on this agency, the Canadian International Institute for Peace and Security, and discuss why it should not be included in this bill. I hope that members from the government side will consider supporting this position.
The government's own briefing notes say that the mandate for CUPS is: "To increase knowledge and understanding of the issues relating to international peace and security from a Canadian perspective, with particular emphasis on arms control, disarmament, defence and conflict resolutions". Look at the conflict resolutions in the world: Yugoslavia, Vietnam, Cyprus, East Timor, Sri Lanka and on and on. At a time in our era when we need advice on how to help bring about conflict resolution, whether through the United Nations

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
or the CSCE or through whatever means, we sign the death warrant for CUPS.
The members from the Official Opposition raised this matter under estimates in our standing parliamentary committee. We called as a witness before us Mr. David Brady, who is the chairman of the board of directors of CUPS. We called as a witness Mr. Bernard Wood, who is chief executive officer of CUPS. After hearing testimony from these two gentlemen all members of the standing committee came to the conclusion that the government is not saving any money by cutting CUPS because a lot of the work that is being done and a lot of the archives that have been collected must be transferred over to the Department of External Affairs. At that meeting, a letter was circulated to us from the hon. member for Scarborough East. He talks about grants. I will not have time to go through all that. But he says:
Aside from grants, CIIPS operates many other activities. These include a series of well-researched publications such as the annual Guide to Canadian Policies on Arms Control and Disarmament, Defence and Conflict Resolution as well as the Quarterly Peace and Security magazine-all of them authoritative and free from the bias that has reflected badly on the granting program. May I suggest, therefore, that the Minister of Finance might wish to consider either of these courses of action:
1.	Terminate CIIPS as announced, but arrange that the outstanding, approved grants be honoured in respective programs that are already in progress, or-
2.	That the future of CIIPS be reviewed with a view to its continuation -
This is from the the Conservative member for Scarborough East. It has been tabled. It has been read into the record in our standing committee. That was the feeling of all the members in the standing committee from all three parties.

It has no other choice. If it does not, then I am afraid that we will be looking at a lot of-I do not want to use the word hypocrites because that is not parliamentary-people who said one thing in the standing committee and will be doing another thing in this House when they vote.

I will be looking across the floor when we are voting on this bill and I hope that at least all the members from the Standing Committee on External Affairs and International Trade will be voting against this bill.

I want to ask my colleague how would he see the effect of the closure of this institute on Canada's image and ability to remain as a leading force internationally when it comes to foreign affairs and when it comes to policies affecting the peace and security both abroad and regionally.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Bill C-63 is a piece of legislation to give effect to a portion of the elimination or deferral or privatization of some 46 government agencies.
The bill before us is concerned with the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, the Law Reform Commission of Canada, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the Economic Council of Canada, the International Centre for
Ocean Development, and the Science Council of Canada.
If we look at all 46 agencies involved in the budget announcement, I think most of us could see some logic in the elimination of some and the privatization of others. But when I look at the list that is contained in this legislation, I am struck by what my Liberal colleague said earlier when he reflected upon the fact that the elimination of these agencies was deemed by the government to reflect a rationalization.
Without looking in the dictionary or recalling the dictionary definition that was read to us, I think one of the things we would expect of rationalization is that it at least be rational. The total cuts that were announced for all those 46 agencies will amount to something like $22 million a year.
I just want to call to your attention, Mr. Speaker, the expenditures that are being made by this government in another area. I picked this area because it seems, in proportion to the expenditures made and what is being sacrificed to save $22 million, so ridiculous, so useless and so irrational. I am speaking of the prosperity initiative the community talks. In Windsor we had one of those community talks. It could hardly be called a community talk. It could have been called almost anything except that. It involved perhaps 30 or 35 people.
For those community talks occurring across the country with an average attendance of somewhere between 40 and 50 people, the government is going to spend $3.2 million. For public relations and advertisement it is spending $5 million. That, with everything else, will give a total of $19 million spent for the prosperity initiative, something that I think most of us now agree is an entirely useless activity-and I chose this example because of the irony involved-particularly in view of the fact that prosperity initiative has a great deal to do with the role, the past work, and what could have been the work of the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada.
It is not rational in terms of savings, but it might be rational from another point of view. I have said before it is my view one of the things that has been bad about this government, certainly in the view of most Canadians, is that it has used its two majorities to implement an ideologically based program which resists any consulta-
April 30, 1992

tion, any advice or any input of an effective character from the people at large.
We have ended up with almost eight years of the most arrogant, ideological and absolutist government this country has ever seen. It is a government that does not use advice and it particularly does not want, it appears, to have good and well researched advice. That is what underlies the demise of certainly the Economic Council and the Science Council. Much the same could be said about the Law Reform Commission and the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security.
The Law Reform Commission of Canada is something that I thought was of absolute value to the advance of law in this country. I am shocked, as I am sure most Canadians are shocked, that the government has apparently decided that it is not necessary to have a mechanism by which the Criminal Code can be reviewed on the basis of the kind of research and informed opinion that the Law Reform Commission has brought to us. Yet we hear almost daily from the people about their concern about Criminal Code misapplication.
We also hear a great deal from many elements in our country, the minorities and native people, about the failure of law to them. I suppose it might be suspected that underlying the demise of the Law Reform Commission of Canada is part of a pattern of not wanting to get the bad news because the government would have to do something that is not completely in line with a preformed ideologically based idea of what should happen.
The Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security is an interesting one. It is an institution that is valued by Canadians and respected internationally. By and large it has reflected the Canadian ideal of a role in securing peace and disarmament in the world and for finding alternative mechanisms for the settlement of international disputes.
It is curious that the termination of the Institute for International Peace and Security should come at a time when within this House there has been a fair amount of controversy about what seems to be a defence policy still resident in the cold war. We are busily, it seems, building our own military industrial complex as a basis for
Government Orders
economic policy in the face of the development of an appropriate civilian economic or industrial policy.
I suppose it can be said, therefore, that these decisions the Minister of National Defence has announced over the past week, and others yet to come, would be confronted with the kind of criticism this government would not want to see led by such a prestigious institution. We could argue, as it can be appropriately argued for almost all of these killed institutions, that the government killed it as it has killed the others because it cannot stand criticism. It cannot stand informed opinion calling into question policies or legislation by this government that might be appropriately questioned on well researched and well justified grounds.
I think that the sorriest actions have been the killing of the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada. The Economic Council is another prestigious institution that has had much to say which has been critical of government, but I think just yesterday it demonstrated its usefulness in its report on education in this country. The picture the Economic Council painted is one of horrific problems that, if not addressed, could lead to an increase in the next decade in the number of functionally illiterate adults in this country of one million. It portrays a picture, not of a Canada that is number one but a Canada that among industrial nations is sliding down toward the middle or worse in a number of areas.
I know that most of us have become used to the notion that Canada is characterized as spending more than any other industrial nation on education, but on a per capita basis we sink to only the average.
Figures show that of our youth between 16 and 24 years of age, above 40 per cent are functionally illiterate and innumerate. That is to say they cannot read and they cannot count. At least they cannot count well enough to tally up a grocery list and they cannot read well enough to understand what is in the newspapers.
It shows that in comparison to other countries which depend a great deal on vocational training and apprenticeship and industrial training, that we lag behind them by orders of magnitude, particularly Germany and other European nations.

April 30, 1992
Government Orders
It says that this country needs leadership if we are going to be economically successful in producing within our country a focus on education, obviously implemented within provincial jurisdiction which is in accord with our desire to produce a nation that can use technology, science and research and development to yield the kind of jobs and economic prosperity that this country needs.
Unfortunately, and this is the rub, the Economic Council has been critical of the government from time to time. Therefore, it was killed. I am sure that others have already addressed with a significant degree of anger the killing of the Economic Council.
The one that is closest to my heart is the Science Council. It ought to be of concern to all Canadians that a Prime Minister who said in 1983 that unless we enhanced our technology and our research and development we would end up in the minor leagues of international competitiveness.
The fact of the matter is that we have ended up in the bush leagues. We have yet to develop an independent polity, apart from the free trade agreement which is really the only economic policy this government has so far produced. What the government has done in terms of science shows little progress at all.
The Science Council has been the only independent source of advice on science policy this country has had. It has been a productive institution, an institution that has identified many of the problems which are now common knowledge. It has addressed the need for changes in education, in the diffusion of technology and a whole host of things ranging from the environment to the place of women in science.
I just want to read a few of the titles of the reports and discussion papers that the Science Council has released because it shows the scope and in some ways responds to the argument of the government that there are other institutions that somehow can fulfil the role of the Science Council.
Among the significant reports are the following: Not a Long Shot; the Canadian Industrial Science and Technology Policy; Winning in a World Economy; University and Industry Interaction on Economic Renewal in Canada; Technology in the Canadian Forest Product Industries; the Seeds of Renewal; Biotechnology and Canada's
Resource Industries; the Uneasy '80s; the Transition and Information Society; Science for Every Student; Educating Canadians for Tomorrow's World; Science, Education and Canadian Schools; Science, Technology and Constitutional Change; Firing up the Technology Engine; Strategies for Community Economic Development.
Those are just examples. Of course, if you want to cite some of the pioneer works, the Science Council was the first to suggest the separation of waste. This lead to the blue box programs that are being used in a lot of municipalities. As I said earlier, it also identified the inadequacy of representation of women in science and engineering.
The Minister of Industry, Science and Technology, the Minister of Science, would say: "Well, we have the National Advisory Board for Science and Technology". But the National Advisory Board advises the Prime Minister. Its reports are not public. They are released at the convenience of the Prime Minister. We also have to understand that its reports are rather narrow in scope. Its focus increasingly with the elimination of representatives from government departments and the wide-scale elimination of academics from the councils is largely devoted to the issue of science and technology and industrial development. That is an appropriate emphasis for that kind of body.
We know there are other concerns related to science in this country both in terms of the positive contribution that science can make from the point of view of industrial policy, in terms of protecting and enhancing the environment, about the values in our country which have discouraged the study of science, about the impact of inappropriate policies based on science that can lead to harm, about the necessity of a partnership and the introduction of technology.
There is a whole host of topics that the National Advisory Board on Science and Technology could not provide us with.
In other countries there is the Royal Society or the science academies that have provided characteristically to some degree the kind of policy advice and research that the Science Council has provided to Canadians. Unfortunately in this country, those institutions are not sufficiently developed to provide that here. Our institution was the Science Council.

I listened as my Liberal colleague pointed out that the committee on external affairs had an opportunity to hold hearings on the demise of ships. I want it known here that unfortunately, an attempt to look at the question of the Science Council and the Economic Council by the committee on industry, science and technology was prevented by a concerted packing of our committee on behalf of the government including a parliamentary secretary who said that because this legislation was before the House we could not deal with it, an argument not made in the committee on external affairs.
I have heard government members talking about royal commissions, the research branch of the library, some of the science departments, NRC, NSERC, and so on as fulfilling the role of the Science Council. These suggestions can all be dismissed.
The fact of the matter is that the committee on industry, science and technology said that the Science Council should be strengthened. It should be provided with more and secure funding. Remember, this government's first action with respect to the Science Council was to cut its budget from about $20 million to $5 million. It asked for yearly reports. In fact the Science Council is about to produce a report on technology and industry and 15 sectoral studies.
