April 30, 1992
Private Members' Business

That in the opinion of this House, the government should examine
the possibility of adapting to Canadian conditions and experience
some training and apprenticeship programs which have been
successful in Germany and Sweden.
He said: Mr. Speaker, as political leaders of this nation, we have the great responsibility of creating an environment and vehicles of opportunity for our people.
Our nation desperately requires new ways for dealing with the contemporary challenges we face. This country needs a new contract, a contract that addresses the effects of the changing global dynamics, the need for an equal partnership that includes the key players in the economy.
We need a new contract in order to modernize our economy, get it moving again, create high skill, high wage jobs and redefine the relationship and the roles of government and the individual within our society.
Today I rise to address this House on a subject of great importance to Canadians and to the future of this nation, namely, apprenticeship training. It is an important component of the new contract. Clearly, apprenticeship training is a vehicle of opportunity for millions of young Canadians who have not been given a fair chance by our system. It is a subject which is slowly gaming prominence in the national consciousness.
Finally, business people, politicians, media and others are starting to recognize the critical role that training plays in a nation's economy. Slowly, people across Canada are also awakening to the sad state of our educational and apprenticeship training system. They are coming to the realization that something must be done. Indeed, something must be done. Our nation is heading for a crisis unless governments, business, labour, the educational sector and individual Canadians start to co-operate on this issue.
All the players must come together and in an equal partnership must work together to build a comprehensive national apprenticeship training plan that Canadians so desperately need. This is not a simple task. Traditionally the relationships between the different players have
been examples of confrontation instead of co-operation. That is the past. It is now time for all the parties to put aside their individual histories and look toward a common future.
It is time for the federal and provincial governments, business, labour and the educational sector to sign a new contract. It is time for new ideas.
What we need is a revolution in our thinking. Government can be a positive force in the area of apprenticeship training. As a facilitator and guide, it can ensure that genuine progress is made. Government has a responsibility to take the first step toward reforming our present apprenticeship training system. Failure to act will lead to an inevitable erosion of our high standard of living and global competitiveness.
This is not an exaggeration. As a nation we cannot afford a high school drop-out rate of 30 per cent or 100,000 students a year. We cannot afford a 38 per cent adult illiteracy' rate. We cannot afford to have 1.5 million people on unemployment insurance, including 400,000 young people, while 300,000 jobs go unfilled. The present system simply does not work and it must be changed. One of the first changes to be made is how our society views apprenticeship training.
In Canada, apprenticeship training is not generally considered to be a worth-while career path. Hundreds of thousands of young people are directed away from rewarding, challenging careers because of our society's poor attitude toward the skilled trades. That is wrong and it must stop.
Another problem with our present system is that the availability of training is often limited to a small segment of the population.
Finally, because of jurisdictional barriers, the completion of a training program in Canada does not guarantee national recognition. Such problems can only be solved through a complete overhaul of the existing apprenticeship training system. We must discard that which has failed and adopt new practices, new approaches.
As we look for ways to reform our system, we should consider the German model which has been phenomenally successful. Germany performs better than Canada on most levels. Germany's drop-out rate is less than 10 per cent compared to Canada's 30 per cent. Germany has a stronger commitment to research and development and a much more inclusive approach to labour relations.
April 30, 1992

But it is in the area of apprenticeship training that Canada looks the weakest compared to Germany. The two countries vary greatly. The number of apprentices in Canada is 122,000 for .81 per cent of the work force.
In Germany, the number is 1.8 million or 4 per cent of the work force. In Canada, the average age of an apprentice is 26 and in Germany it is 17. The average length of an apprenticeship in Canada is four to five years and in Germany, it is two to three.
There are also important differences in the costs. In Canada, the apprenticeship costs $170,000 over five years and wages are $120,000 over five years. In Germany, the cost of the apprenticeship is only $51,000 over 3.5 years and the wages are only $25,000 over the same time.
How can the German system produce so many more skilled workers in less time and with less money? There are a number of reasons. An examination of the German system will illustrate some of them. Under the German system, streaming begins much earlier, between the ages of 10 and 12.
When compulsory education ends at 16, young Germans have four options: unskilled labour, full-time technical training, higher academic studies and the dual system of apprenticeship training and schooling. As is the case in Canada, 30 per cent of students choose to pursue higher academic studies. However, 60 per cent choose apprenticeship training.
By the age of 16, these students have entered a dual system through which they can combine vocational training in a company with theoretical and practical education in a classroom. German companies play an indispensable role in the German apprenticeship system. That is because they understand that apprenticeship training is more than temporary job creation. It is also an investment in the future.
These companies are willing to pay the price because they recognize the double benefit of apprenticeship training, a permanent supply of skilled labour as well as a stable society. The commitment of German employers to education and training is an example that Canadian stakeholders must follow. If we are to build the learning
Private Members' Business
culture that the government speaks of, our industries must become centres of life-long learning.
This is especially important when one considers that approximately three quarters of those Canadians who will be in the work force by the year 2000 are already in the labour market.
As technology changes, as the nature of their work varies, these people will need the skills to adapt to rapid transformations in the work place. The German model is also relevant in this instance.
The dual system geared to young people is only one element of a wide-ranging apprentice training system. Germans continue to improve their skills or to acquire new ones throughout their careers. The result of this continuous training has an important influence on their personal advancement.
Consider the following: More than one in four executive managers of the largest companies started as apprentices. Almost half of them returned to school to obtain a post-secondary diploma. One third of these companies trained their executive managers. Two thirds of Germany's engineers started their careers as apprentices in the dual system.
In 1988, 35 per cent of the population between the ages of 19 and 65 was enrolled in continuing education courses, more than half being directly related to their jobs. This attachment to the apprenticeship training on the part of German individuals and firms is an important element of a progressive, industrial strategy.
A highly skilled work force can adapt easily to changes in technological application and organizational structure, two factors in measuring an economy's competitiveness. Competitiveness must be an important concern of Canada's if it is to succeed in the global marketplace. The development of a national apprenticeship training program is, therefore, in the interests of our different levels of government as well as that of our industries.
Again, important lessons can be learned by studying the German model for Germany, like Canada, is a federal state. In Germany, education is primarily the responsibility of the lander or individual states. Guidelines for apprenticeship training are set by the standing conference of the ministers of education, which includes a representative of the federal government.

April 30, 1992
Private Members' Business
In contrast to Canada, the school systems of the different lander are highly standardized. In order to adhere to federal guarantees of freedom of movement and occupational choice, the curriculum evaluation systems and structure of the different states' educational systems are very similar. It is clear that Canadians are handicapped by a lack of co-ordination similar to that found in Germany. Provinces have traditionally paid more attention to their narrow interests at the expense of national considerations. Fortunately, however, provincial governments are beginning to realize that this restricted outlook can have serious negative results.
The Council of Ministers of Education has taken the first tentative steps toward increasing the level of co-ordination between their departments and the call for national testing is supported by almost every provincial government.
On the education front, the different levels of government are slowly starting to make progress. In other areas, however, we still lag behind Germany. For example, in the area of labour market policy it is customary for Canada to emphasize income maintenance or unemployment insurance at the expense of active programs like training and employment creation. According to the OECD, the federal government spends only 25 per cent of its labour market program's budget on active programs; the other 75 per cent going to income maintenance.
The Conservative hands off approach to apprenticeship training is the total opposite of that which we see in Germany. The success of the German system is proof of the important role that government plays as an active partner in the process, helping to co-ordinate labour market and educational policies.
The government's role of co-ordinator and regulator is just as important as business' role of provider. A strong partnership based on the participation of different levels of government, business, labour, educator and individual Canadians is the necessary foundation of a successful apprenticeship training system.
Besides the existence of a strong partnership, another reason for the success of Germany's apprenticeship training system is its reliance on an institutional model
for easing the transition from school to work. The most important feature of this model is the high degree of co-operation and interaction between those involved in education and training. Schools, companies, labour and governments all act in concert. With this level of interaction it is easy for a student to see the correlation between education and career opportunities. From an early age young Germans are exposed to the realities of the labour market and are, therefore, able to make more informed career decisions.
In contrast, young Canadians are given only superficial guidance in their career decisions. Faced with an abundance of sometimes conflicting information and without much help in analysing the data, many students make choices which they soon regret.
The general indifference of Canadian employers toward the education system is also a cause for alarm. Only by involving themselves in the educational process, by introducing in-house training programs, can Canadian firms avoid debilitating labour shortages in the future.
Finally, governments must also accept their responsibility in this area. First they must develop a spirit of co-operation between the major players, but they must also act with determination, introducing regulations and guidelines that will ensure that training programs are introduced.
Some will say that we need made-in-Canada solutions for made-in-Canada problems. I agree, but I also know that we can always learn from the success of others. While there are important cultural differences between Canada and Germany, there is still much in the German model that can serve as inspiration to us as we reform our apprenticeship training system. That reform is a prerequisite to the future prosperity of Canada.
Once we have put in place a serious, national apprenticeship program, we can start to build the kind of economy that Germany has traditionally enjoyed. We can build on traditional strengths like our abundant natural resources and our young population, but we must also give ourselves a world class apprenticeship training system. We cannot allow the world to pass us by.
April 30, 1992

It is this government's duty to see that work begins immediately on a Canadian apprenticeship training program. Our future depends on it.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am happy to have this opportunity, along with my colleagues, to respond to the hon. member's motion concerning, and I quote:
- examine the possibility of adapting to Canadian conditions and experience some training and apprenticeship programs which have been successful in Germany and Sweden.
I would like to begin by assuring the House that the issue of developing effective training and apprentice-like programs in Canada is a very high priority for this government. Currently the whole area of school-to-work transition is being closely examined by the federal government and the private sector. Through the Canadian Labour Force Development Board and the prosperity consultations, there are major initiatives under way to develop new strategies to facilitate this transition from school to work.
The government has been addressing this issue because we inherited a skills training legacy that was clearly inadequate to meet the career aspirations of an increasing number of Canadians as well as the competitive needs of Canada as a whole. In fact, entry level training options in Canada all too often lack relevance, responsiveness and consistency in our regions.
The result is that too many Canadian young people, and I am not only referring to school dropouts, seem to, in a sense, fall between the cracks of the labour market. A recent Canadian Chamber of Commerce report expressed concern, and I quote: "that there is a serious shortage of skilled trades people to meet certain skill needs in the work force. Not enough young Canadians are choosing skilled trades and technology careers".
Clearly addressing this problem is, in large part, the responsibility of our formal education systems, our employers and all other labour-market partners. The historical absence of co-ordinated school to work transition programs for our non-college bound young people has also contributed to this unacceptable solution.
The government supports and continues to pursue an objective of making the school to work transition more
Private Members' Business
effective, not just through band-aid remedies but through long-term solutions. Clearly this is not a cyclical problem, but is a structural problem. As such it requires long-term and lasting solutions that will help Canada fully utilize our human resources in an increasingly competitive global marketplace.
As my colleagues will explain in more detail, the government has explored a variety of means to reinforce and better co-ordinate training in Canada. For instance, co-operative education has been revitalized through the Labour Force Development Strategy's support. Co-operative education has long been acknowledged as an effective mechanism to introduce young people to the job market. Our strength and commitment to co-operative education focuses on high school students with particular attention given to potential drop-outs.
Linking all areas of our effective and innovative youth program is a continuum of emphasis on the importance of training and skills development, not just during the so-called school years, but throughout an individual's life.
The highly successful Challenge Program was created nine years ago on the premise of providing young people with relevant job experience.
I mentioned earlier the training initiatives being developed through the Canadian Labour Force Development Board and through prosperity consultations. The CLFDB, if I may use that terminology, made up of stakeholders from all relevant sectors; business, labour, education, social action groups and governments, has identified school to work transition as a priority over the next two or three years. As a result, they are conducting research on this issue and will likely examine further the types of systems in other countries, such as the German dual apprenticeship system.
It is expected that the subcommittee will report its initial findings by September of this year. As well, the issue of school to work transition has been discussed at length within the prosperity consultations. Results to date from all levels of consultation, community portfolio and national, confirm that there is a significant interest in this issue.

April 30, 1992
Private Members' Business
Proposed solutions include an expansion of co-op education and the development of more apprenticeshiplike programs, modelled possibly on the German apprenticeship system. These and other related areas are expected to figure in the prosperity action plan due to be released this fall.
It should be stressed, however, that while there is much to learn from Germany and other models including Sweden, there are considerations particular to Canada that must be taken into account.
I note that the hon. member's motion quite rightly takes this into account when it speaks of "adapting to Canadian conditions and experience" programs from abroad. Let there be no mistake, there are significant differences to be considered, a fundamental one being the level of private sector involvement.
For instance, in Germany the private sector for all intents and purposes owns the system and takes full responsibility for its development and application. The German dual system of apprenticeship is already strongly established in the German private sector to ensure that employers develop the prerequisite entry level skills in their labour market. Clearly such important initiatives depend on a strong commitment from the private sector, both philosophically and financially, a commitment that in Canada until recently has been most notable by its absence.
It is no secret that compared to some of our major competitors, the level of Canadian private sector involvement for in-house and other training programs is not even in the ballpark. Clearly we need a greater commitment from the private sector, not only because it is fiscally unacceptable for governments to simply throw money at this issue, but also because in the final analysis business and industry know what they require to succeed.
Surveys indicate that many Canadian employers are dissatisfied with the skills and job preparedness of high school trained employees. Yet at the same time, not enough firms in Canada invest in training.
Responding to this critical situation, the government has made unprecedented efforts to build practical, effective and relevant partnerships with employers and other labour market stakeholders.
As my colleagues will spell out in some detail, we are now seeing the positive results from these efforts, both
in terms of specific partnerships and a growing general awareness in the private sector of the need to apply their experience and resources to the development of a training culture in Canada.
It is clear that the significant element of that training culture must be technical education and entry level programs that will involve all partners. In this context, the government has a crucial role to play as a catalyst and as a facilitator, supporting and promoting the development of innovative, co-ordinated training initiatives that will ensure national prosperity.
In closing, let me emphasize again the importance the government attaches to this issue. We understand how closely tied our success as a nation is to the quality of education and training we provide to an emerging work force. Related to this we understand as well that the critical issue raised by the hon. member's motion must be addressed, not just by government but by all Canadians if effective solutions are to emerge.
This is a strategy this government has pursued and will continue to pursue in the days which lie ahead.

Mr. Speaker, in the limited time available I will only be able to make a few remarks.
Let me first congratulate the parliamentary secretary for his skilful reading of his notes. What he forgot to mention in his intervention is that the committee report entitled "Human Resource Development" is one year old and is still waiting for its implementation. Therefore, the beautiful expression of interest and commitment just made by the parliamentary secretary falls on deaf ears, because we do not see any action on the part of this government.
In addition, I would like to draw attention to the excellent report by the Economic Council of Canada which came out yesterday, entitled "A Lot to Learn- Education and Training in Canada". Some very interesting points are made in that report.
I would like to make sure that all members are aware of the fact that this report is the swan song of the Economic Council of Canada. It is the last report to be produced by this excellent council.
Why? Because in the budget speech of February 25, the Minister of Finance announced the killing of this
April 30, 1992

council as well as the Science Council of Canada, the Law Reform Commission, the Canadian Environment Advisory Council, and other important institutions such as the Canadian Institute of International Peace and Security. He said it was a budget measure to reduce expenditures and to increase efficiency to Canadians.
That is not the reason why it is being cancelled along with the Economic Council. It is because the Minister of Finance has decided he can get better advice from within his department than by maintaining and encouraging the life and activities of important councils including the Economic Council of Canada which has to say: "In Canada vocational preparation is not treated as a credible alternative to the academic stream in secondary schools".
On page 41 it says: "The Canadian apprenticeship system is limited in coverage and is not responsive to labour market needs".
I can only commend and congratulate the member for York North for his terrific motion today because it allows us to focus on an issue which the party in power has neglected since 1984. The reason I say that is that while the previous federal government was involved in funding apprenticeship programs it was cancelled by this government a few years ago. Therefore eliminating once and for all any federal presence and any federal support behind apprenticeship programs. That was the end of it.
Unfortunately it was not just that which the government did. It cancelled the agency I mentioned earlier, the Economic Council of Canada, an institution that just now has begun to draw the attention of the government and the public to the shortcomings in our educational system.
Canada is almost the only economically advanced country that has no national education standards of any kind. How can we become globally competitive without national standards in education, without national input and support behind the apprenticeship system my hon. and distinguished colleague from York North has so skilfully produced in the House of Commons? How can we do that?
How can we practise the lofty themes developed by the parliamentary secretary, for whom I have the highest esteem, particularly when he enters the field of education, when we lack the instruments, when we lack the political will, when we cancel the budgetary measures which are necessary to implement apprenticeship mea-
Private Members' Business
sures, when we lose the political will which is necessary to establish national standards, when we actually witness a constant retreat in governance on the part of this government.
My time is up. We are sharing the time, the member for York West and myself, so I will relinquish my time to him. I am convinced he can carry on extremely well and I thank you for your attention.

Mr. Speaker, it is very difficult to fill the large and impressive shoes of the member of Parliament for Davenport. Let me start by commending my colleague, friend, and neighbour for putting this motion because it is most timely.
Unfortunately the message is not a new one. We say over and over in this Chamber and across the country in various discussions that we pay people on unemployment insurance $12,000 per person. We pay welfare recipients, once they have exhausted unemployment insurance, $12,000 a year per person so they may survive. For the majority of those individuals it is a very sad situation with employment and the economy unfortunately shrinking as opposed to being vibrant and stimulating. Often those people are vegetating, not through their own wishes and aspirations, but almost as a forced circumstance imposed on them by a system.
We have, as has been mentioned by both my predecessors, a restructuring taking place. We have a world that is changing. We have a world that certainly does not owe us a free lunch and that is not going to wait for us in terms of trying to catch up.
Most observers agree with that analysis. Most individuals on unemployment insurance would agree with that. Most welfare recipients would agree with that. Most academic and educational institutions would agree that the time has come to change or reform our thinking in terms of training and apprenticeship programs.
The $64,000 question is: "Where and why is there no action? Why is there a lack of reform? Why is there a lack of political will to make the transition?"
If as has been mentioned the Germans have a good model or the Japanese have a good model, they are by no means leaders in every category of the apparatus. Clearly there have been enough success stories in both the European model and the Asia-Pacific model to point to the worthiness of having an apprenticeship program that offers a future, if not for older Canadians, clearly for younger Canadians.

April 30, 1992
Private Members' Business
Many people suggest that we should be linking unemployment insurance with training procedures. Both the unemployed and those who are successful and lucky enough to have jobs agree with that. Some feel that more and more of their income is going toward sustaining individuals, allowing them to survive without upgrading their individual attributes, and if individuals do not upgrade themselves the country's work force does not upgrade itself. There will be no net wins emanating from that system.
My father is a tool and die maker. He owns his own tool and die shop. I am very proud of him because he came here like thousands and millions of others with very little schooling and very little in his pockets. Thanks for the opportunities of this country he was able to provide for himself and his family. My father tells me that we are still going to Europe, particularly to Great Britain, to import tool and die makers. Why? It is because our schools in this country are not producing tool and die makers to meet the market demand. We do not have apprenticeship programs to allow businesses like my father's to assume tool and die makers who can make a go of it. That is a shame.
An attitudinal change needs to happen. Why? It is because many people have told their sons and daughters not to do what they had to do. Sometimes there is a stigma. Youngsters have to go to university and not do what their forefathers have done. There should be no stigma attached to being able to work with one's hands. There should be no stigma attached to being an electrician, a carpenter, a plumber, a mechanic, a tool and die maker. Those positions will never be replaced by the computer. Those positions will always continue to have their value.
While they suggest that somehow a graduate of university is more special than someone who may have graduated with a licence in plumbing, never mind the stigma, we do not offer the opportunity for the apprenticeship programs that should be available for individuals who wish to pursue a career by working with their hands as opposed to working with only their brains pushing paper at a desk.
Speech after speech, study after study indicates that we are not moving in that direction. Therefore that is why this motion is valuable. That is why this motion is
timely. If the government is going to speak about global competitiveness, world economies, freer trade, increased competition, prosperity agendas, and giving the tools to our youth, what does that mean to the average 21-year-old who wants a niche and a place in his or her own world? It means very little unless we begin to enter the world of pragmatics and practicality when it comes to having a career. That is why I hope the House supports my hon. friend's motion.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to respond to the hon. member's proposal. It is an interesting one that deserves our attention. To say that young Canadians are the future of this country may be a cliche, but the fact remains that this is quite true. In any case, I am sure that all members will agree that the best possible programs should be available to our young people to help them make the transition from school to the job environment.
Our government has already stressed the need for building a skilled and productive labour force, in a publication entitled Agenda for Economic Renewal, a program announced after the 1984 election. Since then, we have initiated a number of activities in co-operation with our partners in the private sector, to provide workers with the kind of training they will need to ensure Canada's prosperity beyond the year 2000.
Hon. members will recall that the Canadian Labour Market and Productivity Centre examined our programs to assist transition from school to the labour market and made recommendations for improving them. The hon. member would probably be interested to know the conclusions being considered at this time by the Canadian Labour Force Development Board. One of the commission's subcommittees is considering ways to reach the approximately 60 per cent of young students who take no further training after leaving high school. Some of these students leave with a diploma, while others are part of the 30 per cent that drop out of high school.
Our government is a firm believer in partnership, and our partners in more than half of our leading industries have expressed their dissatisfaction with the level of skills students have acquired when they leave high school.
April 30, 1992

Furthermore, on the subject of job preparedness, managers of more than 60 per cent of small businesses are dissatisfied with the way high schools prepare their students for the labour market. Generally speaking, the public is rather dissatisfied with the performance of the Canadian education systems. Over 50 per cent of Canadians believe that our youngsters do not acquire even the basic skills, while only 30 per cent believe that they are well prepared to join the labour force.
These are but a few examples of the kind of challenge facing us. I must tell my hon. friend that the days when government was expected to solve our problems are gone. Nowadays, we have to team up with the private sector, i.e. businesses, workers and community leaders who understand the special needs of the work environment. Such co-operation already exists. The Canadian Labour Force Development Commission is made up of 22 leaders representing the business community, labour, educational and training institutions as well as social action groups.
As I said, the commission takes a close look at initiatives to facilitate school to work transition. While progress has been made toward creating strong partnerships with private sector stakeholders, I must admit that a greater involvement on the part of the private sector should be encouraged, because only 31 per cent of Canadian businesses are offering their employees regular training.
Another study shows that 15 per cent or less of the work force has received limited job-related training. Youth unemployment is higher than for the overall population.
This is one more reason why it is urgent that we come up with an appropriate basic skill acquisition scheme and a system to determine whether a potential worker has the skill level required for the job.
The motion put forward by my hon. colleague deals with the possibility of adapting to our needs some training and apprenticeship programs in use in other countries. I can assure him that we are indeed drawing from the experience of our competitors in an effort to adapt and compete on the global market.
Private Members' Business
Thanks to the information that we have gathered, we know of several international models that ensure a smooth transition from the high school to various careers and professions. For instance, in Germany, the apprenticeship program used by the private sector was expanded to enable employers to give workers a chance to acquire the skills they need to be eligible for top jobs.
I was saying a moment ago that a greater involvement from the private sector is necessary. I was thinking of the excellent initiative of a Canadian corporation from Mississauga, Siemens Electric Limited. This company has set up an apprenticeship program patterned on the German model. This program emphasizes the need for an integrated system which would encourage high school students to consider a career in various trades, lower the drop-out rate in apprenticeship programs, improve the content of education programs, and ensure fair access to the system for candidates.
This concept, which was developed by one of our partners from the private sector, would help correct the flaws of the present system and would enable us to develop the specialized trades that our country needs to remain competitive.
The issue of transition from the school to the labour market, which was the topic of studies done by the Canadian Labour Force Development Board and by partners from the private sector such as Siemens Electric, were also discussed during our consultations on prosperity. These consultations required more than 200 meetings in communities across the country. The results of those meetings were sent to a steering committee whose members represent a large sample of Canadians from all walks of life. The steering committee is expected to publish this fall an action plan which will serve as a guide for governments, businesses, workers, university people, scientists and Canadians in general.
I can assure my hon. colleagues that our prosperity initiative is entirely conducted by the private sector. It is the responsibility of the federal, provincial and territorial governments to create a favourable climate for the successful transition from the school to the labour market. However, this environment must lead to the continuous acquisition of knowledge.

April 30, 1992
Private Members' Business
The federal government will do its share. However, the success of this initiative depends on the full co-operation as well as the efforts of our partners. We are starting to see this co-operation. If we unite our efforts, we will be able to develop a strategy for the transition from school to the labour market which will ensure a promising future to young Canadians. This will in turn ensure Canada's competitiveness during this decade and into the 21st century.
I congratulate my colleague for his proposal, which definitely deserves the support of the members of this House.

Mr. Speaker, I too feel privileged to support my colleague from York North. It was not too long ago that he put forward another private members' bill in this House respecting the Oakridges moraine, the largest body of underground water in Ontario. He proposed to turn most of that body of land into a national park. I supported him in that notion. I hope we can continue to promote the protection of that land in our province.
The issue of apprenticeship is important, especially today, because we are no longer able to afford the luxury of counting on our natural resources to meet the cash flow requirements of this country. For years and years we as a country have been spoiled in the sense that we could export our raw materials which would bring in the necessary cash to operate our treasury and the social programs that gave us the standard of living we all enjoy.
Today we are dependent more than ever on our ability to manufacture, on our ability to make things with our hands. The entrepreneurship of this country cannot expand its basic business unless it has a properly trained work force around it.
I had the opportunity from 1984 to 1986 to work for Magna International. This is an organization founded by an Austrian entrepreneur who came to Canada with I do not think any more than $1,000 in his jeans. I see my colleague from Newmarket in the House who knows this organization well because many of his constituents work in Magna factories throughout his area. That was an experience where I really learned the importance of apprenticeship.
This was a man who, because he had this skill of making things with his hands, was able to create a business that in over 15 or close to 20 years created 15,000 manufacturing jobs in this country. He was able to do it because every year he had very strict control over the amount of money that went into apprenticeship. He would say time and time again that the strength of that organization was the apprenticeship programs and the apprenticeship system that the corporation had.
The problem that he would bring to my attention and others' attention-some of us are in government now and he has asked us to bring this message-is that if we would support small and medium sized manufacturers in this country in the area of apprenticeship, our job opportunities for this country could expand overnight.
When there are quality apprenticeship programs, then a work force is created that has the talent to make a better product at a better price. That of course is what this competitiveness issue is all about.
We cannot expect this to happen on its own. People in industry need support. With the economic conditions as they are today, with banks cutting back on small and medium sized entrepreneurs in terms of their credit lines, it is very tough for them on their own to create these apprenticeship programs or to create an apprenticeship condition within their corporations. They are counting on us as politicians and as people who are affecting public policy to make sure that this issue is looked after.
That is why the motion of my colleague from North York is so timely and so appropriate. Last year, in this country we spent close to $35 billion on welfare payments and unemployment insurance payments. Had we redirected or if we had linked some of that money to the idea of a national apprenticeship program, it would have been a much better investment for this nation. This is where we seem to be lacking in creativity.
I know my colleague, the member or Winnipeg South Centre, when we had a similar recession back in 1981 and he was the minister of employment came up with the NEED program. It was essentially a national apprenticeship program where the government would top up or assist the employer in the funding of the person's wages if that person had been taken off welfare or the unemployment insurance rolls. That was one of the most successful programs that we have ever had in this country in terms of putting people back to work and
April 30, 1992

giving them skills that will be with them for the rest of their lives.
That is where I think this government has really failed in the last two years through this very deep recession, where it has basically retreated from the exercise of creativity. The government has retreated from trying to figure out ways that it could top up that unemployment insurance fund or re-design the welfare system in a way that while there is a down period in the economy, we could be investing that money in a proper apprenticeship program.
That is an area where, as national politicians, if we do not focus on it, if we do not give it the necessary thrust, then the entire manufacturing capability in this country is going to become weakened and it is going to put us in an inferior position.
Earlier today I was going through a householder put out by my colleague, the member for Davenport, entitled, "Ready to Meet the Challenge." He devotes his entire householder to apprenticeship, all the various occupations and all the potential job opportunities that are out there. If we were to support these programs, our unemployment rolls would diminish very quickly.
I salute my colleague from York North for once again taking the initiative on a very important issue like this. I hope we can have the support of all members in this House.

Mr. Speaker, I wanted to stand up and commend the hon. member for York North for this motion. It is something I know he believes very strongly in. We have talked in the past about the need for apprenticeship programs. I was very interested to hear some of the comments today and the support that there is generally throughout this House for this very important project.
One of the things that we as members and we as a society have to look at when we look at apprenticeship programs is the apparent feeling in this country right now and in the last few years that in order to be successful in today's modem world that one must have a university degree and the skills and education that go along with that.
When you look at the business people today who are successful, who are doing well in today's climate, doing
Adjournment Debate
well internationally and proving themselves, they are people who have learned their skills the hard way. They have learned their trade, their ability to run a business, for the most part through the school of hard knocks, which is the expression that is often used. That is something we have to get through to our young people today. We have to encourage them to go out into the world and to learn and understand the needs of today's society.
I was talking to some people who were suggesting that bricklayers in this country are averaging 59 to 60 years of age. It will not be very long before those very bricklayers are not going to be able to perform their particular skills and crafts and we are going to need people to replace them. These are the people today who in the future are going to have the opportunity to be very, very successful economically, socially and really be able to contribute a lot to this world we live in.
There are a lot of things that we could talk about when it comes to apprenticeship, whether it is competitiveness in the future or just our whole educational system, something that the provinces have been dealing with for a number of years. We have gotten away from the trade school atmosphere that we had in our high schools a generation ago.
I realize we are out of time, but I would like to just finally commend the member for York North for bringing this motion forward. I am sure that in the future we will all be supporting this very type of action.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to take the few minutes available to me to review a question that I posed to the government back on February 10.
That question had to do with an earlier decision in January when this government essentially gave away the store on the whole question of the generic drug industry at the GATT meetings. The government proposed to extend the current licensing to some 20 years, which effectively places in serious jeopardy and danger the whole question of generic drug firms versus the large pharmaceutical firms.
I do not have anything against the pharmaceutical brand name companies for the work that they have done, for the research and for the drugs they come up with for Canadians and people around the world, nothing at all. There needs to be some sort of protection, maybe copyright, for the work and the research invested in the drugs that they have produced.
At the same time, the generic drug industry which employs some 3,000 people across the country and allows a moderation of prices in prescription drugs has been a made-in-Canada solution that has worked well. It has offered balance and it has offered fairness. It has offered fairness to the large multinational corporations that put their drugs on the market, have had a monopoly for a number of years on that particular drug, have made back what they have invested and on top of that have made a very decent profit.
After that, we have the generic drug firms allowed by legislation in this country to essentially manufacture and produce those same drugs at a lower cost.
It seems to me that balance has worked fairly for the pharmaceutical companies, the generic companies and most important, for the consumers. This is at a time when we are hurting economically, at a time when Toronto is losing jobs, when the two largest generic companies in the country are located in Toronto, Apotex in my own riding and Novopharm in the larger metropolitan area in the east end, namely Scarborough.
When we are talking about hurting economically and then the whole debate about the crisis facing our health
care system and the soaring prices for both patients and institutions, why would we place a strait-jacket on the generic drug firms at this particular time?
Therefore, my question was aimed at trying to have the government recognize the sensitive balance and the important role that generic drug firms, both from an economic and a medical point of view, have played. I hope that the parliamentary secretary responding today on behalf of the government will bring us some much needed good news.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Thank you, Mr. Speaker, for the opportunity to speak to the House, albeit briefly, on a very important issue.
I would like to begin by stressing the fact that there has been a very considerable amount of consultation with the industry, including the generic companies, over the course of these many, many months. In fact, I am informed that there have been some 15 meetings in total which took place between the spring of 1991 and the announcement in January 1992 to which the hon. member has referred.
Furthermore, I am also advised that the proposed changes which, indeed, would be consistent with changes occurring elsewhere in the industrial world will not limit the opportunity of generic companies to continue to function in Canada and to continue to have a profitable experience.
All existing generic products will continue to be available and the number of new generic products can also be introduced under compulsory licences which were issued before December 20, 1991.
It is important to stress that those pharmaceutical companies make heavy financial investments in the area of research must have the opportunity to earn a return on that investment if they are to locate in our countiy.
We are at a stage in our history when nations around the world are making locational decisions. If we are to be out of step with other potential climates for investment we will suffer. The net result will be that there may be less investment in Canada, and perhaps less investment in important research.
April 30, 1992

All of us are consumers of that successful research. We are a net beneficiary of that process.

Mr. Speaker, every day that I spend in my constituency office I hear from engineers, architects and builders. They tell me just how bad things are economically in metropolitan Toronto.
Quite frankly, most of them do not know where their next job is coming from. One very large engineering firm with a million dollar payroll tells me that it has no more work orders on the books whatsoever.
How can they possibly have any work to do when there is no one out there building anything in metropolitan Toronto? Why would anybody build anything at all when right across from my own constituency office in an industrial commercial zone 30 per cent of the industrial commercial buildings are vacant? They are not doing anything.
There are signs on the windows saying: "Job Action Centre". There are all sorts of things like that. Somehow we have to create some more jobs. It seems to me that one of the best ways to do that is through construction itself.
In its recent budget the government and the Minister of Finance announced the 5 per cent down payment for housing and the use of Registered Retirement Savings Plan moneys for housing construction and for housing purchases. Those are excellent initiatives, and I want to congratulate the Minister of Finance on them, but we need more.
One of the other ways that we can get more is to push ahead with the CMHC housing development projects. There are a number of those in the works and they have been in the works for some time. They are at various stages of development but they are all there ready to go and we should be taking advantage of that.
One, in metropolitan Toronto, is the Downsview property. Another is the CMHC Toronto branch land site. Another near metropolitan Toronto is the Vaughan property. Out in British Columbia there is the Kitsilano project and in the Vancouver area the George Derby site. In Montreal there is the Benny Farm site.
Adjournment Debate
We are not lacking for a number of potential projects. All we have to do is get on with them and go ahead with them.
As far as the Downsview site in Toronto is concerned, I am not referring to the Canadian Forces military depot. I am talking about the 135 acres of property that CMHC already controls, that has nothing to do with the military depot. CMHC has a plan to build 5,000 affordable houses on that property.
If we did that, we could produce jobs for carpenters, plumbers, electricians, architects, engineers, builders, building products suppliers, furniture and appliance dealers and manufacturers. Each new home actually creates two person-years of work, so we need these jobs. We do not need that land being sold off to some private developer. We need the government to go ahead and start building on those lands now.
I hope that tonight the parliamentary secretary will confirm that is exactly what we are going to do, that we are going to build on those lands now and we are going to create some jobs.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member referred to one of the recent government initiatives which I think is of extreme importance.
He referred to the fact that the required down payment had been reduced from 10 per cent to 5 per cent.
I would just like to inform the members of the House the results of that program have been very significant. In fact, according to my information, as of April 3 over 12,500 Canadian households have made use of this initiative to purchase their first home with a down payment of 5 per cent. That is probably greater than had been anticipated. The success of that initiative is evident.
As you also know, I think there has been some significant progress with the Downsview project to which the hon. member referred. Certainly, it got off to a slow start and the hon. member is well aware of that. However, following negotiations relating to the sale to Boeing of a division of de Havilland it is anticipated that formal applications for planning approvals can now be tabled with the city of North York.

April 30, 1992
Adjournment Debate
The CMHC, the Department of National Defence, and the Treasury Board are looking at other areas within the base itself which could allow the housing development to be undertaken in an earlier timeframe.
There is also activity going on at the George Derby project in Burnaby. At the Kitsilano redevelopment project in Vancouver the first new building is being occupied and tenders have been closed with the second building. Therefore, there is evidence of activity here. I trust that the hon. member will be pleased to hear that.

Mr. Speaker, on February 6 I asked the finance minister about the government's commitment to keep its promise that the goods and services tax would not be charged on the necessities of life. It is clear that water is one of those necessities, yet the finance minister has seen fit to impose the GST on the delivery of that very basic commodity to 26 communities across Saskatchewan.
The GST is everyone's nightmare, despised by 75 per cent of Canadians who quite rightly see it as the biggest tax grab in Canadian history.
When the GST legislation was introduced this government promised that the basic necessities of life would be exempt from the tax and that the tax would be fairly and equitably applied.
Endless problems have been created by the GST affecting consumers, business, even with regard to the bureaucracy created to administer it.
In November 1991 the Minister of Finance decided to apply the GST to water. Surely, a basic necessity but to some Canadians not to all Canadians. This is not exactly an equitable or fair arrangement.
To add insult to injury the government imposed the tax retroactively, taking an extra $319,000 in GST from Saskatchewan in 1991, including $7,500 from Warman, $7,300 from Martensville, $4,000 from Domremy, and $3,000 from Osier each year. In Saskatchewan right now we have a situation in which the GST is applied to water for some Canadians, but not to all. This is hardly fair, hardly equitable, as the government promised.
On March 10 in a bulletin the Department of Finance admitted that the application of the GST on water is unfair and inequitable.
I raise the issue on behalf of over 2,000 families in Martensville, Warman, Domremy and Osier, communities in Saskatoon-Clark's Crossing. I ask why these people should be forced to pay the GST on water when others do not. Over 700 families wrote to me to complain that this was a most unfair situation. On two occasions I rose in the House and asked the Minister of Finance questions. I asked him if he would at least look into the implications of the tax and perhaps consider scrapping it.
In response, the Minister of National Revenue said the short answer to this question is no.
In response to another question on April 7 he said that the answer to this issue is for the provincial government in Saskatchewan to harmonize the GST with the federal government's GST. In other words, more tax. Surely, that is a ridiculous answer to the question.
The province of Saskatchewan has made an offer to ensure the elimination of GST on water would be revenue neutral for the federal government, but the department of revenue insists that the Saskatchewan Water Corporation, a Crown corporation, must assume municipal status. The Saskatchewan Water Corporation is most emphatically not a municipality. The federal government must look at the situation realistically and change the rules to fit the facts of life not change the facts to suit its regressive policies, which the government admits are unfair.
The government must rescind the GST on water. It has reneged on its promises of a fair and equitable tax. It has reneged on its promise to exempt basic necessities from the GST. Two thousand families in Saskatchewan are forced to pay an unfair, inequitable tax, one that the government admits is unfair and inequitable. They are forced to pay it retroactively because the government is, for reasons of its own, unable to accept the province's offer which would resolve the problem. It is time for the government to take action, time for the Minister of Finance to assume some leadership here. Two thousand families should not be paying the GST on water. It is time for the government to stop breaking its own promise and scrap the GST on water.
April 30, 1992

speakeroldname: Mr. Barry Moore (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Revenue):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Revenue
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would just like to point out that the GST replaced an outdated and inefficient federal sales tax that freed up business from an archaic and inefficient tax and replaced it with a simpler and more equitable one.
Turning to my colleague's remarks, I want to emphasize that municipalities receive a partial rebate of any taxes paid by them on their inputs. This ensures that they do not pay more tax than they did under the previous FST system.
That's not true.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Revenue
speechtext:
Oh, yes it is true.
Moreover, municipalities do not charge GST on the vast majority of standard residential services, including the provision of water. Simply put, consumers do not pay GST on supplies of water provided by municipalities.
In fact, under the GST a mechanism has been provided to allow provincial government agencies such as the Saskatchewan Water Corporation to ask to be treated like a municipality when it performs municipal functions.
In other words, households in Saskatchewan do not need to pay GST on water. The means are in place for the Saskatchewan Water Corporation to ensure that supplies of water are exempt from the GST. This mechanism was provided to ensure competitive equity between municipalities and other organizations that supply water.
I would suggest to my hon. friend in closing that the solution to this matter lies with the provincial government rather than with the federal government.

Mr. Speaker, on April 1, I raised with the hon. Minister of National Health and Welfare the issue of foetal alcohol syndrome and the use of warning labels on alcoholic beverages as a means of coping with this problem.
The minister responded that the problem was simply a B.C. problem and there was no proof that warning labels would in any way deal with the preventive aspects of this problem. This is simply not the case.
Our health issues committee has heard from parents, care givers, professionals from all parts of Canada, from the Atlantic region, the Yukon, the prairies, central Canada and British Columbia, about the seriousness of this problem.
At least 1,500 foetal alcohol syndrome children are bom each year in Canada. The cost of maintaining services for these children is in excess of $1.5 million for each child. Foetal alcohol syndrome is the leading cause of mental retardation in Canada. In addition, foetal alcohol effect is one of the major contributors to learning disabilities, to developmental delays and behavioural problems that our school systems, mental health facilities and correctional facilities are forced to cope with.
The alcohol industry spends $250 million a year on advertising for alcohol. Between them, Labatt's and Molson's spend $115 million. By the time a child reaches the age where it can legally drink, it will have been exposed to 100,000 ads, television or electronic commercials for alcohol.
All the professionals who appeared before us have advocated the use of labels as one part of a preventive problem. The most telling tale about why the industry is opposed to the use of labelling has come from marketing
experts. I want to read the statements of Dr. Gurprit Kindra, associate professor of marketing at the University of Ottawa. He explains very clearly from a marketing perspective, not from a health perspective, as to why the alcohol industry is opposed. I quote:
Information on the package plays the role of a salesperson. Information that appears on the label can also be viewed as an advertisement. So, warning labels in a way imply forced de-marketing from the brewers' and distillers' point of view.
Labelling is part of an extremely delicate balance of the product mix. The reluctance on the part of the brewers and the distillers, in my opinion, to go along with warning labels is therefore entirely understandable from a marketing viewpoint. They're really being asked to modify their product, and that is a very sensitive issue.
The delicate balance of the product mix is based on dreams, aspirations and desired lifestyles. A warning label of any kind will ruin the fun theme that is generally associated with beer and alcohol.
In other words, the concern is that warning labels will ruin their fun theme. He goes on to say:
I believe that the hazard signs are an important part of any risk-reduction strategy-Readability, perceptual prominence, and colour contrast should be the three guiding principles of technical appropriateness. The statement on the sign should be clear, graphic, succinct, to the point, singular, and specific.
In other words, he is saying warning labels do in fact reduce the consumption of alcohol during pregnancy if they are properly applied.

speakeroldname: Mr. Barry Moore (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Revenue):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Revenue
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the foetal alcohol syndrome represents the extreme end of the spectrum of adverse birth that comes related to alcohol use and abuse during pregnancy.
Recognition of these problems is relatively recent in part because they are often difficult to diagnose at the time of birth.
It is believed that FAS is more likely to occur in cases of abusive drinking, often combined with poor nutrition and smoking, but no safe level alcohol consumption can be defined for a pregnant women and her foetus.
Health and Welfare Canada has supported a number of initiatives over the past 10 years in this area of concern. They include a national research symposium in 1983, an FAS education package and resource kit in 1989, and most recently the community project Crabtree in Vancouver and many other projects.
April 30, 1992

With respect to the proposal to put warning labels on alcoholic beverages, the minister has already indicated he wants to consult the provinces and the territories. In addition, he has asked his officials to mount a co-ordinated departmental effort to look at the difficult issue of FAS more closely. Also the department looks forward to the report and recommendations of the parliamentary committee currently studying this matter.
Foetal alcohol syndrome is a tragic and complex problem. There are no simple solutions. We look for-
